title: Soul Power
brief_description: In 1974, music producers, Hugh Masekela and Stewart Levine worked with the boxing promoter, Don King, to create a music festival in Africa to run concurrently with his championship boxing match he arranged with Muhammad Ali and George Foreman, aka "The Rumble in the Jungle," in Kinshasa, Zaire.
description: In 1974, music producers, Hugh Masekela and Stewart Levine worked with the boxing promoter, Don King, to create a music festival in Africa to run concurrently with his championship boxing match he arranged with Muhammad Ali and George Foreman, aka "The Rumble in the Jungle," in Kinshasa, Zaire. However, due to an unforeseen delay due to Foreman injuring himself in training, it was decided that the music festival must still go on as scheduled. This film covers the preparation of that festival with both stage construction and the arrival of the participating musicians. When all is ready, the people of Zaire got to experience a musical event that Africa had never seen before with great African-American and local artists performing with verve and purpose, with the Godfather of Soul, James Brown, just the biggest star of this musical extravaganza.

title: "Write Your Life," 6-Part Writing Workshop
brief_description: We will take on the anxieties and fears around writing and provide you with tools to help turn down the noise and start writing your story
description:
Join this 6-part writing workshop with Teri Carter to take on fears about writing and gain tools the to start writing your life story.


"Write Your Life"

6-Part Writing Workshop with Teri Carter

Saturdays 9:30 to 11am: March 14, March 21, March 28, April 4, April 11 & April 18

Early Bird Price (20% January Discount): $160 for 6 Classes

Regular Price: $200 for 6 Classes

(All fees donated to JSP nature and art programming)


Writing our real-life stories sounds easy and even enjoyable until we sit down with a sheet of paper and feel immediately stuck. Where do I start? Can I write that about my mother, my kids, my job? How do I approach family secrets, abuses, taboos? What if I write my story and someone tells me I remembered it all wrong? We will take on the anxieties and fears around writing and provide you with tools to help turn down the noise and start writing your story.


This class will take place at Josephine Sculpture Park indoors and outdoors, as weather permits.


Registration Required: Maximum 8 Students - Purchase online via eventbrite (registration + service fees), or contact us for payment via cash or check. Note for online purchase: Even though the workshop date on eventbrite only lists March 14, your purchase ensures your registration for all 6 Saturdays.


About the Instructor

Teri Carter writes about politics and women’s rights for the Herald-Leader, the New York Times, and The Washington Post, and she is working on a memoir about step-parenting. She mentors writers at the Carnegie Center in Lexington and teaches classes in memoir writing, personal essays, newspaper opinion, and developing essay collections. For more information about Teri and her work, visit her website at TeriCarter.net.

title: The Babushkas Of Chernobyl
brief_description: In the radioactive Dead Zone surrounding Chernobyl’s Reactor No. 4, a defiant community of women scratches out an existence on some of the most toxic land on Earth.
description: In the radioactive Dead Zone surrounding Chernobyl’s Reactor No. 4, a defiant community of women scratches out an existence on some of the most toxic land on Earth. They share this hauntingly beautiful but lethal landscape with an assortment of interlopers—scientists, soldiers, and even ‘stalkers’—young thrill-seekers who sneak in to pursue post-apocalyptic video game-inspired fantasies. Why the film’s central characters, Hanna Zavorotyna, Maria Shovkuta, and Valentyna Ivanivna, chose to return after the disaster, defying the authorities and endangering their health, is a remarkable tale about the pull of home, the healing power of shaping one’s destiny and the subjective nature of risk.

title: Impulso
brief_description: The spectacular avant-garde choreographies of flamenco dancer Rocío Molina have electrified audiences around the world. Her extravagant, mesmerizing and mostly improvised pieces combine traditional Flamenco with modern-dance, avant-garde theatrics, objects, paint, and eclectic music compositions.
description: The spectacular avant-garde choreographies of flamenco dancer Rocío Molina have electrified audiences around the world. Her extravagant, mesmerizing and mostly improvised pieces combine traditional Flamenco with modern-dance, avant-garde theatrics, objects, paint, and eclectic music compositions. Impulso is an intimate portrait of Molina, one the dance world's most passionate artists, as she travels the world to perform her improvised "impulsos" at unusual venues ranging from prisons to modern art museums. Now Molina must prepare for one of her most challenging works ever for a new show at Chaillot National Theater in Paris. Despite Molina's unconventional stagings and artful theatrical setups, she remarkably manages to maintain her connection to Flamenco's rich history and traditions.

title: What They Said in Public, works by Megan Bickel
brief_description: An opening reception will be held on Friday February 28, 6-8 PM for "What They Said in Public", featuring new works by Megan Bickel in the Wilson Gallery.
description:
An opening reception will be held on Friday February 28, 6-8 PM for "What They Said in Public", featuring new works by Megan Bickel in the Wilson Gallery.


In What They Said in Public, multimedia artist Megan Bickel spends a considerable amount of time meditating on two words as they relate to one another in this contemporary moment: illusion and allusion.


Illusion — of course—references a trick, has a visual connotation, and is typically used to describe the rendering of an image. An allusion, on the other hand, is primarily literary and depends on the imagination of the viewer. Interestingly, there appears to be a contradiction in these two similar ideas that display a very specific power dynamic between purveyors of visual and purveyors of written information.


Here, the power dynamic that Bickel is referencing can at times appear malignant in its presentation. Meaning, for the illusion, that there is a historical power to deceive in a way that may appear psychologically threatening when considered by the viewer. This threat doesn’t appear as strongly in the allusion because in the act of reading a text the viewer (or reader) is reliant on their own imagination. Thus, all of the conjured imagery or ideas that arise during reading are contingent on what they have consumed prior.


The above information is critical for the artist when considering her process, areas of research, and material usage as she has a tendency to lack a loyalty to subject or material and is instead interested in conceptual misinformation and how that idea can be relayed. Looking at perceptual psychology, sociological camouflaging, propaganda, political science, advertising, science fiction, anthropology, and art history (specifically Post-Modern and Post-Digital Painting) she offers summated opportunity for the audience to consider misinformation in the Digital Age.


Materially speaking, she is approaching this conceptual problem by mimicking painting with materials that reference, or are in fact “ a painting” while lacking several of the qualities of a painting. For example, by digitally collaging segments of her paintings, printing them on to a decal, and then painting a mural depicting the shadow of a painting as a way to reference a painting as an object; she utilizes perceptual and periphery visual mapping to confuse the viewer of what they are seeing until further inspection—of which becomes clear after moments of consideration.

Believing that it is ethically problematic to believe that a visual artist has the ability or skill to “teach” a public (or assume their interest) about the wrong-doings of contemporary images; Bickel instead hopes that by cultivating systems of confusion, the exhibition space can become a sort of mental exercise— training the audience mind to consistently question the intent of the image-maker in our contemporary world. A world where election fraud and manipulation of public media consumption during political campaigns can be completed on the other side of the world— as an act of war.


Megan Bickel is a multidisciplinary artist and writer based out of Louisville, Kentucky. Bickel is currently working toward her Master of Fine Arts at the University of Louisville and received her BFA and BA (Magna Cum Laude) from the Art Academy of Cincinnati in 2012. She has since then been included in numerous solo and group exhibitions, and interviewed in publications regionally and nationally.


Megan is also the Founder and Gallerist for houseguest, a house gallery ran parallel to her partner, Jacob Wilson’s (Sous Chef, 610 Magnolia), SUPPERCLUB LAB. houseguest encourages artists to interact with and activate the gallery space while exploring new ideas and concepts that feel respective to the zeitgeist and beyond.

Bickel was the Co-Founder and Editor of Five-Dots (2016-19), a digital publication that covered the Midwest, ran in collaboration with photographer and LGBTQ+ activist Cassandra Zetta. Bickel is a regular contributor to Aeqai, a non-profit arts periodical based out of Cincinnati, Ohio.

title: Shelter
brief_description: A subtle thriller set in Germany involving Mona, a Lebanese woman (played by Iranian-born, Paris-based star Golshifteh Farahani), and Naomi, an Israeli Mossad agent (Neta Riskin) sent to protect their informant who is recovering from plastic surgery to conceal her identity.
description: A subtle thriller set in Germany involving Mona, a Lebanese woman (played by Iranian-born, Paris-based star Golshifteh Farahani), and Naomi, an Israeli Mossad agent (Neta Riskin) sent to protect their informant who is recovering from plastic surgery to conceal her identity. Together for two weeks in a quiet apartment in Hamburg, the two women take us into a complex, multi-dimensional labyrinth of trust and mistrust, of honesty and deception, of loyalty and betrayal. The intimacy of the relationship that develops between Mona and Naomi is exposed to the threat of terror that is engulfing the world today. In this game of deception, beliefs are questioned and choices are made that are not their own. And yet their fate takes a surprising turn in this suspense-laden, elegant neo-noir.

title: The Public
brief_description: In "The Public" an unusually bitter Arctic blast has made its way to downtown Cincinnati and the front doors of the public library where the action of the film takes place.
description: In "The Public" an unusually bitter Arctic blast has made its way to downtown Cincinnati and the front doors of the public library where the action of the film takes place. At odds with library officials over how to handle the extreme weather event, some homeless patrons turn the building into a shelter for the night by staging an "Occupy" sit in. What begins as an act of civil disobedience becomes a stand-off with police and a rush-to-judgment media constantly speculating about what's really happening. This David versus Goliath story tackles some of our nation's most challenging issues, homelessness and mental illness and sets the drama inside one of the last bastions of democracy-in-action: your public library.

title: 2020 Lexington Gathering
brief_description: The Lexington Gathering is a four-day winter music festival bringing some rural America's richest cultural traditions to downtown Lexington.
description: The Lexington Gathering is a four-day winter music festival bringing some rural America's richest cultural traditions to downtown Lexington. We welcome hundreds of visitors from across the country into this bucolic, walkable downtown for a weekend featuring the “old masters” of traditional mountain music; dance callers from throughout the state; performances by accomplished and emerging string bands; youth workshops and performances; academic presentations; jamming for all skill levels; dance, singing, and instrument workshops; literary readings; instrument and art vendors; and some of our finest farm-to-table eating experiences. Kentucky’s rural diaspora is a lineage largely responsible for the Commonwealth's unique and diverse cultural heritage. Because these Kentuckians migrated to nearby urban centers for work and education, Lexington is a perfect place to explore the boundaries of these traditions and enjoy the melting pot revival of these arts.

title: Front Yard Art Show Lex
brief_description: You make art (in WHATEVER way you interpret that), you put it for display in your yard
description:
During times of increased anxiety and social distancing measures creating ART and COMMUNITY is more important than ever.


This movement will be a community led event so please join us!


What is a Front Yard Art Show?

You make art (in WHATEVER way you interpret that), you put it for display in your yard and then your address is added anonymously to a map that will guide people around Lexington to view ART safely from their cars! 🚗 🚙


For now mark yourself as GOING, SHARE this event with your friends and neighbors, and begin thinking about what YOU and your family can make to display!

Perfect for families!!!


Best practices:

*We want to make this event family friendly so please make all art/ creations appropriate for little viewers as well.

*Make it viewable from the road! The goal is that cars passing will be able to see it WITHOUT having to leave their car.

*Use what you already have! No need to make unnecessary trips to the store! Get creative!

*Have fun!


***I will be adding a Google form to anonymously collect participating address next week. PLEASE DONT COMMIT TO ADDING YOUR ADDRESS IF YOU ARENT GOING TO PROVIDE AN ART/ CREATIVE DISPLAY


Want to help out?

Any other questions/ ideas/ marketing strategies can be sent to Sarah at frontyardartshowlex@gmail.com


Woot woot!!

Can’t wait!!!

title: Denise Webber: Life Lines, opening reception
brief_description: Denise Webber (b1958 Leicestershire UK) is a British artist whose work spans video, drawing, and photography. Her work has featured internationally in exhibitions at Tate Modern London, Moderna Museet Stockholm, and the Museum of Contemporary Art Melbourne and is represented in the Arts Council England Collection and the Tate Archive. Her work in Life Lines explores the female body and its complicated relationships to beauty, creative authorship, and power.
description:
Denise Webber (b1958 Leicestershire UK) is a British artist whose work spans video, drawing, and photography. Her work has featured internationally in exhibitions at Tate Modern London, Moderna Museet Stockholm, and the Museum of Contemporary Art Melbourne and is represented in the Arts Council England Collection and the Tate Archive. Her work in Life Lines explores the female body and its complicated relationships to beauty, creative authorship, and power.


Exhibition curated by Stephen Wrentmore, a British theatre director, producer, writer, academic, curator, change consultant, and arts leadership advisor. He teaches directing and Shakespeare at the University of Kentucky in the Department of Theatre and Dance.

title: The Most Massive Woman Wins
brief_description: The Most Massive Woman Wins- Challenging, brutal and hilarious, four women of various shapes and sizes sitting in the waiting room of a liposuction clinic explore their perceptions of body image.
description:
-The Most Massive Woman Wins-

Challenging, brutal and hilarious, four women of various shapes and sizes sitting in the waiting room of a liposuction clinic explore their perceptions of body image. The women reveal their experiences dealing with their weight issues through monologues, short scenes, and even schoolyard rhymes. From painful childhood memories to frustrations with the opposite sex, these experiences both haunt and empower these women as they imagine their way to a new vision of themselves as beautiful and whole.

Directed by Taylor Crumrine

FREE ADMISSION!

Friday 2/21/20 @5PM & 7:30PM

Fine Arts Building Rm.102

title: All Them Witches at The Burl
brief_description: By most fifth LPs, the band’s sound is pretty set. All Them Witches go a harder route.
description:
All Them Witches at The Burl

Lexington, KY - SUPPORT TBD


Wednesday 4/29/20

Public On Sale: 11/22/19 at 10AM EST


DOORS: 7PM

SHOW: 8PM

ALL AGES


https://www.etix.com/ticket/p/2179188


ALL THEM WITCHES


By most fifth LPs, the band’s sound is pretty set. Parameters established. Refinement dissipated. You get a to-formula execution of what’s worked in the past. Fair enough. All Them Witches go a harder route.


In 2017, the Nashville four-piece offered what might’ve otherwise become their own template in their fourth album (second for New West), Sleeping Through the War. It brought a larger production value thanks to oversight from producer Dave Cobb (Jason Isbell, Shooter Jennings, etc.), found them using choral vocals, expanded arrangements, bigger sounds than anything they’d done before.


They could’ve easily fallen into a pattern of watered-down clones of that record. Easily.


So naturally in a year they’ve thrown it all to the Appalachian wind, turned the process completely on its head and gone the other way: recording in a cabin in Kingston Springs, about 20 miles outside of Nashville on I-40, with guitarist Ben McLeod at the helm. Self-produced. Take that, expectation.


The result, mixed by Rob Schnapf (Beck, Elliott Smith, Kurt Vile), is the most intimate, human-sounding album All Them Witches have recorded and another redefinition of who they are as a band. Introducing keyboardist/percussionist Jonathan Draper to the fold with McLeod, bassist/vocalist Charles Michael Parks, Jr., and drummer/graphic artist Robby Staebler, All Them Witches’ ATW isn’t self-titled by mistake.


It’s the band confirming and continuing to develop their approach, in the devil’s boogie of “Fishbelly 86 Onions,” the organ-laced groove and masterful flow of “Half-Tongue,” the build of “HJTC” and the fluid jam in closer “Rob’s Dream.” You can hear it in the mellow patience of that last track, never lost but always wandering, and in “1st vs. 2nd,” where they turn from a frenetic shake to some purposefully metal-ish riffing while still holding onto gut-tightening tension.


And what do they do with that? Some overblown payoff? Hell no. They cut it short, drift into noise and then dig into “Half-Tongue” ahead of the moodier “Diamond,” which, true to its name, seems to turn any light that touches it into a prism. This is a band who delight in the exploration, in finding new rules to break, and in continually learning new ways to do so.


ATW is a reaction to being a “bigger” act. To playing bigger shows, bigger tours, etc. From the sustained consonants in Parks’ vocals, to the sleek basslines that play off the can’t-sit-still-won’t-sit-still swing in Staebler’s drums, to McLeod’s commanding slide in “Workhorse” and drifting melancholy at the outset of “Harvest Feast,” ATW is their laying claim to the essential facets of their identity.


And most crucial to that identity is its shifting nature. All Them Witches didn’t get to this point by resting on laurels, and if anything, the urgency of these tracks – fast pushers and sleepy jams alike – is among their greatest strengths.


It’s a rawer delivery, as stage-ready as the band itself, and it captures All Them Witches in this moment. Is ATW who they’ll be tomorrow? Who the hell knows? Check back in and we’ll find out together. That’s the whole idea.

title: CivicLex Digital Town Hall - COVID-19 & Journalism
brief_description: This Town Hall is the first in a series that will focus on the impact that COVID-19 has had on Journalism in Lexington. This one will deal specifically with the Lexington Herald-Leader, Central Kentucky's main daily newspaper.
description:
This Town Hall is the first in a series that will focus on the impact that COVID-19 has had on Journalism in Lexington. This one will deal specifically with the Lexington Herald-Leader, Central Kentucky's main daily newspaper.

News and information is an essential part of the public health landscape, especially during a crisis. The Lexington Herald-Leader has provided robust coverage of the COVID-19 crisis and has removed its paywall for any article related to the issue. In this Digital Town Hall, we'll talk with Peter Baniak, the Executive Editor and General Manager of the Lexington Herald-Leader about the steps they've taken to ensure information is reaching people and the challenges they face in this ecosystem moving forward.

All you need is a phone or computer to join!

title: Chance McCoy of Old Crow at The Burl
brief_description: Grammy winning indie folk musician Chance McCoy of Old Crow returns to The Burl!!!!
description:
***BEING RESCHEDULED***


Grammy winning indie folk musician Chance McCoy of Old Crow returns to The Burl!!!! After seven years of touring, recording five albums and winning two grammies as a band member of the luminary Americana outfit Old Crow Medicine Show, Chance McCoy left in 2019 to start a new musical direction and found himself scoring feature films, including his single 'Whippoorwills' for the film 'The Peanut Butter Falcon'.


He mixes modern and traditional folk music in a dazzling multi instrumental display using live looping and a host of on stage instruments and technical gadgetry for his live shows.


Rolling Stone said "Chance McCoy launches spacey, banjo-fueled stomp into Americana’s outer orbit" and Paste proclaims “He may have one of the better alt-folk debuts of this year on his hands".

title: Front Yard Art Show Lex 2
brief_description: During times of increased anxiety and social distancing measures creating ART and COMMUNITY is more important than ever
description:
The first Front Yard Art Show Lex was such a hit....let's do another!

(I mean having something to look forward to is good right now, right?!)


During times of increased anxiety and social distancing measures creating ART and COMMUNITY is more important than ever.


This movement will be a community led event so please join us!


What is a Front Yard Art Show?

You make art (in WHATEVER way you interpret that), you put it for display in your yard and then your address is added anonymously to a map that will guide people around Lexington to view ART safely from their cars! 🚗 🚙


For now mark yourself as GOING, SHARE this event with your friends and neighbors, and begin thinking about what YOU and your family can make to display!

Perfect for families!!!


Best practices:

*We want to make this event family friendly so please make all art/ creations appropriate for little viewers as well.

*Make it viewable from the road! The goal is that cars passing will be able to see it WITHOUT having to leave their car.

*Use what you already have! No need to make unnecessary trips to the store! Get creative!

*Have fun!


***I will be adding a Google form to anonymously collect participating addresses beginning April 26th. PLEASE DON'T COMMIT TO ADDING YOUR ADDRESS IF YOU AREN'T GOING TO PROVIDE AN ART/ CREATIVE DISPLAY. In the meantime BRAINSTORM an epic idea!


Want to help out?

Any other questions/ ideas/ marketing strategies can be sent to Sarah at frontyardartshowlex@gmail.com


Woot woot!!

Can’t wait!!!

title: Faculty and Guest Artist Recital: Oboe, Bassoon, and Piano
brief_description: Featuring UK's ToniMarie Marchioni with Byunghee Yoo and Oleksiy Zakharov
description:
ToniMarie Marchioni, oboe

Oleksiy Zakharov, bassoon

Byunghee Yoo, piano


Works by Villa-Lobos, Previn, and Poulenc


A native of Ukraine, Oleksiy Zakharov is a freelance bassoonist in New York City. Mr. Zakharov has previously held positions of acting Associate Principal bassoon of Los Angeles Philharmonic, as well as Second bassoon of Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra from 2009 to 2015. Mr. Zakharov has performed as a guest principal bassoonist with American Symphony, ABT, Ensemble Signal, Columbus ProMusica, Beethoven Festival Orchestra, Albany, Princeton and Richmond Symphonies as well as Orchestra of St. Luke's. In 2017 Mr. Zakharov joined the faculty of Mahanaim School of Music and has also previously taught as guest bassoon instructor at the Oberlin Conservatory, the Advanced Bassoon Institute @ Interlochen, and has served as guest Judge for the concerto competition at Indiana University, Jacobs School of Music. While enjoying a freelance performing and teaching career in New York City, Mr. Zakharov is also a bassoon technician and specialist, and spends his free time servicing, restoring and repairing old and modern instruments for bassoonists on the East Coast. Mr. Zakharov received a Master of Music degree from The Juilliard School and a Bachelor of Music from Oberlin Conservatory. Mr. Zakharov also holds a Post-Graduate diploma in Orchestral Performance from Manhattan School of Music. His primary teachers include Patricia Rogers, Whitney Crockett, George Sakakeeny and Barrick Stees.


Pianist Byunghee Yoo is a visiting assistant professor of music in chamber and collaborative music at the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music. She has been invited to perform with the concertmaster of St. Louis Symphony, David Halen as well as judge for the Missouri Music Teachers Association Competitions and Texas A&M University-Kingsville Piano Competitions. Dr. Yoo came to the U.S. after receiving top honors at Kyungwon University where she received her Bachelor of Music degree, as a solo pianist, and Master of Music degree, as a collaborative pianist. She also holds her Master of Music degree in collaborative piano at the Juilliard School under the tutelage of Jonathan Feldman and Margo Garrett. She earned her Doctor of Musical Arts degree in collaborative piano at the University of Texas at Austin, where she studied with Anne Epperson. Dr. Yoo has served as a Vocal Arts Piano Fellow and staff pianist at the Juilliard School, Kaufman Music School, and McDuffie Center for Strings at Mercer University. From 2016-2018 she served as the coordinator of collaborative piano at Truman State University. She has been a staff pianist at Bowdoin International Music Festival since 2010.

title: “The Stuff” @ the Cult Film Series
description:
The Stuff (Larry Cohen, 1985)


The script was an original story by Cohen. He said, "My main inspiration was the consumerism and corporate greed found in our country and the damaging products that were being sold. I was constantly reading in the newspapers about various goods and materials being recalled because they were harming people. For example, you had foods being pulled off the market because they were hazardous to people’s health."


Cohen was particularly influenced by "the sheer volume of junk food we consume every day. We continue to eat these foods despite the fact some of them are killing us. That’s when I started thinking that The Stuff could be an imaginary product— in this case an ice cream dessert— that is being consumed by millions and is doing irreparable damage to humanity. Everybody is gobbling down this yummy food, so how can it possibly be wrong for us?"


Cohen wanted to cast Arsenio Hall as "Chocolate Chip Charlie" W. Hobbs, since he thought he was not only a good actor but also a rising star. The executives at New World Pictures, however, wanted someone more recognizable and thus cast Garrett Morris instead.

title: Canceled --> UnderMain Presents: Critical Mass IV
brief_description: A conversation about art criticism and who gets to decide what. Moderated by Great Meadows Foundation Critic-in-Residence, Kóan Jeff Baysa, with a pop-up exhibition, and special guests
description:
Canceled

A conversation about art criticism and who gets to decide what. Moderated by Great Meadows Foundation Critic-in-Residence, Kóan Jeff Baysa, with a pop-up exhibition, and special guests.

The event is free but reservations are required by emailing reservations@under-main.com. Seating is limited.

﻿

Continuing the vital role that UnderMain plays in the cultural landscape of Kentucky and

surrounding regions, the Critical Mass Series (CM), now in its fourth year, embraces the

present state of art criticism in Kentucky. More broadly, it addresses the misconceptions

regarding Kentucky's creative communities by raising awareness of Louisville,

Lexington, and Northern Kentucky as rigorously growing cultural centers, reflecting the

decentralization of the art world through globalism and the internet. The CMIV Series

acknowledges the relative dearth of critical discourse, the imbalance in the components

of its art ecosystem, and the bias of its demographic divisions. With distinguished

participants situated within and speaking from the audience, the goal is that this event

will engender more conversations and support Kentucky artists' increasingly strong

presence on the national stage.

title: Invisible Ink by Margo Buchanan
brief_description: AthensWest is proud to present a staged reading of Margo Buchanan's exciting new play INVISIBLE INK as the second in its "HorseFeathers" series of new play readings.
description:
AthensWest is proud to present a staged reading of Margo Buchanan's exciting new play INVISIBLE INK as the second in its "HorseFeathers" series of new play readings.


INVISIBLE INK follows about Mary Bowser, an enslaved, educated woman with a photographic memory who worked as a servant in the Executive Mansion of the Confederate President, Jefferson Davis. Beginning in 1863 when the Confederacy appears to be winning the war, Mary poses as an illiterate worker, gains the trust of Davis and passes information that goes straight to General Grant. Davis becomes aware that information is being leaked; spies are sentenced and hung. No one, however, suspects an intelligence breach through the black woman scrubbing the floors. Well, maybe one person does…


The reading will take place at Transylvania University's Coleman Recital Hall, in the Mitchell Fine Arts Building, on Wednesday, March 4 at 7pm. There will be a post-reading discussion immediately afterwards. This is a free event, but donations are gratefully excepted!


The reading will feature Meredith Frankie Crutcher, Kevin Hardesty, Tosha Fowler, E.J. Beatty, Holly Hazelwood Brady, Trent Stephens, John Nicholson, and Joan Rue.

title: Artists Thrive
brief_description: Artists Thrive aims to identify the things that help artists pursue their vision and to enable communities to benefit from the arts
description: Artists Thrive aims to identify the things that help artists pursue their vision and to enable communities to benefit from the arts in all aspects of life. Resources and tools within Artists Thrive help artists, arts organizations, and other groups that work with artists collaborate and craft meaningful stories about why art-making matters. The initiative began in 2016 when a group of arts professionals and artists produced the first draft of this field-wide assessment rubric. Through multiple rounds of feedback, Artists Thrive was publicly launched in 2017. Artists Thrive is driven by a leadership team of artists and diverse collaborators from different sectors and communities across the country and is supported by the Emily Hall Tremaine Foundation.

title: Discover Voice-Over- Online Interactive Webinar
brief_description: Whether you choose to pursue voice-overs part-time or full-time, this could be the game changer you’ve been looking for.
description:
***Multiple dates and times available***

In what could be the most enlightening 1.5 hours you’ve ever spent, this webinar will show you how you can actually begin using your speaking voice for commercials, films, videos, and more. Most people go about it the wrong way. In this introductory webinar, you will learn about a unique, outside the box way to break into this creative, fulfilling, and potentially lucrative industry. Voice-overs can be managed on your own terms, on your own turf, in your own time, and with minimal overhead! Whether you choose to pursue voice-overs part-time or full-time, this could be the game changer you’ve been looking for.

To register for our introductory webinar, visit https://bit.ly/OnAirJustineReiss040420D. There will be a series of dates and times available for your convenience, please choose a time that works best for your schedule!

MEET YOUR INSTRUCTOR:

You’ve heard Justine’s voice in numerous commercials: Starbucks, Toshiba, and Mitsubishi and most recently on the Walgreens’ RED NOSE DAY special. She has worked as a voice-over casting director for more than 20 years! She found her way into VO after success on stage, film and as a Disney Stunt Performer. She enjoys helping others bring their voice to life and inspiring people to pursue their passions for voice-over.


Here’s what Justine Reiss will be covering in the webinar:

COURSE OUTLINE:

-Overview of the voice-over industry

-Demonstration of voice-over technique with two class volunteers

-The numerous career opportunities within this industry

-Unions and how they play a part

-The income potential for full and/or part-time voice-over work

-How to market yourself in this fast-changing industry and how to land work!

-The new industry standards (ie. being able to work from home, recording on your computer or smartphone)

-The equipment and tools needed to get started

-An introduction to the all-important voice-over demo

-Step up the mic and record your own voice-over, and receive a complimentary evaluation of your potential in the industry

COURSE INFORMATION

Fee: $6.95

Limited Class Seats

One Virtual Session

LOCATION:

Online

***Please note, this webinar has a number of dates and times available. When registering, you will be able to choose a date and time that works for your schedule. We can’t wait to have you in class!**

This Monday we gather again to celebrate the beginning on March with a rollicking selection of old time tunes and songs.

This is a weekly jam for enthusiasts of old-time fiddle tunes and songs from the Southern Appalachian tradition. Bring your instrument and join or sit and enjoy. The Broomwagon offers a delicious selection of food and drinks. Social harmony through musical harmony. Open to public, no admission fee.

brief_description: The Lyric Theatre & Cultural Arts Center presents with The Core Ensemble and actress, Shinnerrie Jackson, 'Ain't I a Woman' on Thursday, March 5th, as a part of our Women's History Month programming.
description:
The Lyric Theatre & Cultural Arts Center presents with The Core Ensemble and actress, Shinnerrie Jackson, 'Ain't I a Woman' on Thursday, March 5th, as a part of our Women's History Month programming.


Admission:

$20 GA (+ processing fee)

Tickets can be purchased at lexingtonlyric.tix.com or by calling our box office at (859) 280-2218.


'Ain't I a Woman'

A chamber music theatre work for actress and trio (cello, piano & percussion) celebrating the lives and times of four significant African American Women: ex-slave and fiery abolitionist Sojourner Truth, renowned novelist and anthropologist Zora Neale Hurston, exuberant folk artist Clementine Hunter and fervant civil rights worker Fannie Lou Hamer. Text is by Kim Hines. The musical score is drawn from the heartfelt sprituals of the Deep South, the urban exuberance of the Jazz Age and concert music by African American composers including Diane Monroe. Actress Shinnerrie Jackson plays the four historical characters.


Shinnerrie Jackson has appeared in regional theatre and collegiate theatre in such productions as Guys and Dolls, A Christmas Carol, The Tempest, Much Ado About Nothing, King Lear, All My Sons, The Glass Menagerie, and Raisin in the Sun. Favorite roles include Mama Morton in Chicago (Weathervane Theater), Female Chorus in Electra (Pittsburgh Public Theater), and One Night with Janis Joplin. She has been seen on 30 Rock and in Whit Stillmans’ Damsels in Distress. Ms. Jackson holds an MFA in Acting from the University of Tennessee and a B.M. in Vocal Performance from Oberlin Conservatory. This is her seventh season touring in “Ain’t I a Woman!” Shinnerrie Jackson is a member of Actor’s Equity Association.

title: WEKU Concert Encore Broadcast Series: MAHLER 2
brief_description: WEKU and Lexington Philharmonic bring Symphony Performance to Kentuckians During COVID-19 Crisis
description:
MAHLER 2


FRIDAY, MAY 1 @ 8PM - WEKU Classical (online)

SUNDAY, MAY 3 @ 8PM - WEKU 88.9 (on your radio!)

Originally Performed: September 18, 2015


MAHLER - Symphony No. 2 "The Resurrection Symphony"

Karen Slack, soprano

J’nai Bridges, mezzo-soprano

with combined choirs from: Transylvania University,

Eastern Kentucky University, Asbury University and Berea College


WEKU and Lexington Philharmonic bring Symphony Performance to Kentuckians During COVID-19 Crisis. 


As the longtime broadcast partner of the Lexington Philharmonic, public radio station WEKU 88.9 and LexPhil have agreed to broadcast five encore LexPhil performances every two weeks through the end of June. 


While the Lexington Philharmonic’s 2019/2020 Season has been cancelled, the WEKU encore broadcasts are one way WEKU and the Lexington Philharmonic are helping Kentuckians connect to the music of their orchestra safely at home. The orchestra has also developed an online platform titled LexPhil Living Room, to share musician performance videos, education videos and resources for families at home, and other national and international music resources to provide the community with ways to keep classical music a part of life at home. The WEKU encore broadcast dates and links to listen will also be hosted at the Lexington Philharmonic website. “In times like these, it is human nature to want to gather and support each other. This is a different way of gathering for a concert, yet one that is comfortingly familiar,” says Allison Kaiser, LexPhil Executive Director. “WEKU FM has been an important partner to LexPhil for decades and now is a perfect time to introduce additional ways of sharing the resources of this dynamic partnership. We are very grateful for the generosity of spirit, time and commitment from WEKU.” 


WEKU encore broadcasts of Lexington Philharmonic concerts will be aired on both WEKU Classical, and WEKU 88.9. Following broadcast on WEKU Classical, listeners will have two weeks to tune in online to listen to the concert stream.

All materials included (blocks, paper, ink, cutters)


Learn how to transfer images to a block, carve, ink, and print.


Carve one to two images and walk away with your own handmade prints.


Limited to 10 participants, at least 13 years old


Register at https://www.bgprintmakers.org/classes


Cost: $50/person, $40 for Bluegrass Printmakers members.


Registration deadline: Sunday, March 22

description:

In addition to our publications, we also have hats, socks, T-shirts, tote bags and pencils for sale, produced by Institute 193 for various exhibitions and artists over the years. title: Gallery Hop: Transylvania's CETA Class
brief_description: Enjoy a sneak peak of the exhibit: "If The Earth Could Text" by Transylvania University's Community Engagement Through the Arts Class.
description:
Enjoy a sneak peak of the exhibit: "If The Earth Could Text" by Transylvania University's Community Engagement Through the Arts Class. Explore what emojis would look like if they came from Mother Nature herself. Enjoy tasty treats and beverages as you think about climate change, emojis, and art.


Then join us, Kurt Gohde, Kremena Todorova, and the CETA class on Saturday from 1 to 3pm for a workshop to craft more of the beautiful emojis you saw at our Gallery Hop! No prior experience necessary.

title: Reforest the Bluegrass (At Home)
brief_description: The traditional Reforest the Bluegrass event has been canceled, but the spirit of Reforest will still thrive – with your help!
description:
The traditional Reforest the Bluegrass event has been canceled, but the spirit of Reforest will still thrive – with your help! The city is busy working with sponsors and other partners on ways to get trees to the public so you can plant them at home and in your neighborhoods. Activities in process include:


- Live, online Ask-an-Arborist events where you can learn about the tree species available and the kind of place to plant them

- Distribution points for tree seedlings throughout the community – with information on which tree is which and where they should go

- An online method for reporting what tree you planted and where it went; extra Reforest love if you share a picture of your tree in its new home

- Another Go See Trees nature hunt

- Reforest story time - Facebook Live reading of books focused on trees and the many reasons they are awesome


We can Reforest the Bluegrass while staying safe! Trees will not be available until mid to late April, but stay tuned for details.


---------

El evento Reforest the Bluegrass ha sido cancelado, ¡pero el espíritu de Reforest seguirá prosperando con su ayuda! La ciudad está trabajando con algunos patrocinadores y otros socios para buscar formas de hacer llegar los árboles al público y puedan plantarlos en casa y en sus vecindarios. Las actividades en marcha incluyen:


- Eventos de Ask-an-Arborist en vivo y en línea donde podrán aprender sobre las especies de árboles disponibles y el tipo de lugar donde plantarlos

- Puntos de distribución de plántulas de árboles en toda la comunidad, con información sobre qué árboles son y dónde van

- Un método en línea para informar qué árbol plantar y dónde hacerlo; extra apreciación de Reforest si compartes una foto de tu árbol en su nuevo hogar

- Otra búsqueda en la naturaleza de Go See Trees

- Hora de Cuentacuentos de Reforest- Lectura en vivo a través de Facebook de libros sobre árboles y las muchas razones por las que son increíbles


¡Podemos participar en Reforest the Bluegrass mientras nos mantenemos a salvo! Los árboles no estarán disponibles hasta mediados o finales de abril, pero estén atentos para más detalles.

title: CivicLex Digital Town Hall: Basic Needs II
brief_description: For this Town Hall, we'll be joined by representatives from three organizations that have been focused on improving the living situation of individuals and families in Fayette County for decades.
description:
For many, the Coronavirus pandemic has revealed just how fragile many of our living situations are, but for others, this is nothing new. For this Town Hall, we'll be joined by representatives from three organizations that have been focused on improving the living situation of individuals and families in Fayette County for decades. Brooke Raby of the Hope Center, Laura Carr of Lexington Rescue Mission, and Jeffery White of the Nest Center for Women, Children, and Families will join us to discuss how COVID-19 has impacted their work and what we can do to build a more resilient society once this crisis has passed.

title: Poets Down Yonder, feat. Tina Andry
brief_description: A new monthly open-mic poetry series has begun in Lexington, KY!! Please join us for the second of our series at Pivot Brewing featuring poet, Tina Andry
description:
A new monthly open-mic poetry series has begun in Lexington, KY!! Please join us for the second of our series at Pivot Brewing featuring poet, Tina Andry


-----event information----

Pivot Brewery

sign up, 6:30 PM

open-mic, 7 - 9PM with feature poet Tina Andry

all ages are welcome

Free event but please tip your bartender & feat. poet!!


----- the series backstory -----

Poets Down Yonder is hosted and founded by Jessica Taylor and Maggie Garnett. Both are Transylvania alums and helped re-establish the Transylvanian Literary Magazine on campus. Jessica's love for open-mic poetry nights started at Teen Howl Poetry at Morris Bookshop (founded by Elizabeth Beck) and Holler Poets Series at Al's Bar (founded by Eric Scott Sutherland). Maggie also loved attending Holler and helped start an open-mic on campus with the literary magazine.


We knew Lexingtonians were still writing but thought there was still a thirst for a creative, safe, and inspiring place for poetry. Pivot Brewing readily opened their arms to us and we are so eager to start sharing our words in their space.


-----about the featured poet-----


tina andry is a poet originally from new orleans. she has 3 kids. 2 cats. and one dog. she has a knack for brevity and sarcasm.

Ed McClanahan: Out of Hand

April 16 - May 23, 2020

Virtual Reception: April 16, 6 - 6:15 PM via ZOOM


Please use this invitation link and password to view our ZOOM reception tonight at 6 pm:

 

https://zoom.us/j/95799890660?pwd=emFyYkIzYWp6di9Hc3JWZXFXSG5xdz09

Meeting ID: 957 9989 0660

Password: outofhand

 

Throughout history, artists have used our collective fascination with hands to tell the larger stories of their lives and ours. In the 18th century, Anthony Van Dyck painted subdued self-portraits showing his delicate, elongated fingers resting on his shoulder to show potential patrons how much he values his hands, the tools of his trade. In 1919 Alfred Stieglitz created an entire series focusing just on Georgia O’Keeffe’s hands. One photograph in particular shows a hand placed on her bare breasts; turning what would have been considered an erotic photo into an intimate one. And in 1965, Ed McClanahan, then a burgeoning writer now known for his witty and colorful storytelling, created a series of thirteen drawings of hands as comical and strange portraits.

 

This series of drawings, dubbed McClanahands by their creator, explores an odd and varied spectrum of human emotion—each sporting its own expression and personality. One appears to be daydreaming, fingers positioned in a pose of meditation with eyes closed and mouth upturned in a slight smile. Another shows frustration, its face scrunched with anxiety, holding a stick of dynamite, its fist ready to explode. Others are smoking cigarettes, trying to hitchhike to Tijuana, or flipping the middle finger at onlookers. As a writer, McClanahan focused on hands because they are the vehicle for his writing. He unconsciously chose to draw hands at a time when Americans’ freedom was in the forefront of people’s minds, much as it is again today.

 

Out of Hand is the the first exhibition to focus on Ed McClanahan’s work as a visual artist. In 1962 McClanahan received Stanford University’s Wallace Stegner Fellowship for Creative Writing, after which he was selected for a Jones Lectureship where he taught creative writing until 1972. During his time at Stanford, he befriended Ken Kesey, American novelist and author of One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest. Kesey, together with a number of other notable writers and artists, formed the Merry Pranksters, a group famously known for their journey across the United States to promote American ideals of freedom through LSD. These thirteen drawings, affectionately titled Out of Hand: Ten Schizophrenic Drawings, were made while the artists was living in northern California amongst Kesey and the Merry Pranksters. McClanahan has been widely published with stories appearing in Playboy, Esquire, and Rolling Stone among many others. Between 1975 and the present, McClanahan has written 12 books, including The Natural Man in 1983, and Famous People I Have Known in 1985. He lives in Lexington, Kentucky.

title: KY Artists Care: Color Me Team Kentucky Project
brief_description: Instead of an artist of the week, we are asking for illustrators to come together and create coloring pages for fun, education, to help with anxiety and boredom, anything you can muster up.
description:
Coloring pages needed!!!! Instead of an artist of the week, we are asking for illustrators to come together and create coloring pages for fun, education, to help with anxiety and boredom, anything you can muster up. Let's share our work!


Just draw something (black and white obviously) and send them to us so that we can post them. From there, anyone and everyone will be free to download and print, or request the pages via kyartistscare@gmail.com or direct message. 


We will be posting coloring pages we recieve until all this blows over. We will have weekly artists starting up again, but this is a project we're starting so when boredom and anxiety creeps in, whether it be you, your children, or those you are caring for, we will have original illustrations that you won't find in any book. 


We will give the illustratiors credit. Please consider doing this small task for your community. Anything at all that us, as Kentucky artists can do to help, we will. Art can serve a much higher purpose.


If you're an illustrator who is not from Kentucky, SEND THEM ANYWAY! This project includes everyone during these trying times.


Please no nudity, graphic content, or COVID19 related content. 


Send your coloring pages to kyartistscare@gmail.com 


Thank you.

title: WEKU Concert Encore Broadcast Series: DEEP MUSIC
brief_description: WEKU and Lexington Philharmonic bring Symphony Performance to Kentuckians During COVID-19 Crisis
description:
DEEP MUSIC

FRIDAY, JUNE 26 @ 8PM - WEKU Classical (online)

SUNDAY, JUNE 28 @ 8PM - WEKU 88.9 (on your radio!)

Originally Performed: October 25, 2019

AKIKO FUJIMOTO, Music Director & Conductor Finalist


LIBBY LARSEN - Deep Summer Music

GINASTERA - Harp Concerto, op. 25

Allegra Lilly, harp

BEETHOVEN - Symphony No. 7 in A Major


WEKU and Lexington Philharmonic bring Symphony Performance to Kentuckians During COVID-19 Crisis. 


As the longtime broadcast partner of the Lexington Philharmonic, public radio station WEKU 88.9 and LexPhil have agreed to broadcast five encore LexPhil performances every two weeks through the end of June. 


While the Lexington Philharmonic’s 2019/2020 Season has been cancelled, the WEKU encore broadcasts are one way WEKU and the Lexington Philharmonic are helping Kentuckians connect to the music of their orchestra safely at home. The orchestra has also developed an online platform titled LexPhil Living Room, to share musician performance videos, education videos and resources for families at home, and other national and international music resources to provide the community with ways to keep classical music a part of life at home. The WEKU encore broadcast dates and links to listen will also be hosted at the Lexington Philharmonic website. “In times like these, it is human nature to want to gather and support each other. This is a different way of gathering for a concert, yet one that is comfortingly familiar,” says Allison Kaiser, LexPhil Executive Director. “WEKU FM has been an important partner to LexPhil for decades and now is a perfect time to introduce additional ways of sharing the resources of this dynamic partnership. We are very grateful for the generosity of spirit, time and commitment from WEKU.” 


WEKU encore broadcasts of Lexington Philharmonic concerts will be aired on both WEKU Classical, and WEKU 88.9. Following broadcast on WEKU Classical, listeners will have two weeks to tune in online to listen to the concert stream.

title: Virtual SCAPE exhibition
brief_description: Take a virtual tour of the senior exhibition SCAPE at Transylvania University
description:
Visit the Transy SCAPE – Senior Thesis Exhibition virtually . Venture around a 3D virtual gallery; listen to a Q&A session of students and faculty talking about the works in the exhibition; and take a look through the virtual presentation of images, videos and audio of students discussing their art.


SCAPE features the work of four Transylvania University seniors — two studio art majors and two digital arts and media majors. Through a variety of media — including painting, sculpture, video, projection mapping and video game design — SCAPE explores different planes of understanding such as mindscapes, landscapes, e-scapes and escape. These works touch on themes of reality, grief, meditation, memory, mental health, identity and voyage.   


Contact Anthony Mead for more information.

title: Jurassic Park Talks
brief_description: Introducing Centre College's new #HealthyAtHome activity, a mini-lecture series featuring Emeritus Professors.
description:
Introducing Centre's new #HealthyAtHome activity, a mini-lecture series featuring Emeritus Professors.

In the first installment, Dr. C. Kenneth Keffer, H.W. Stodghill, Jr. and Adele H. Stodghill Professor of French and German Emeritus, discusses a mural his students completed during his spring semester humanities class. The mural is a replica of Sheldon Tapley's "Flowers in a Bohemian Vase"; Tapley is an H.W. Stodghill, Jr. and Adele H. Stodghill Professor of Art at the College teaching drawing courses.

Dr. Keffer discusses the philosophy, influence, and process that went into recreating Tapley's painting as a mural with more than 24 individual student paintings. To watch Dr. Keffer's lecture, click the link below. Subscribe to the Centre Alumni YouTube channel for more Jurassic Park Talks coming soon.

title: What Now, Strategies for the Pandemic.
brief_description: Find out what two local entrepreneurs have done in planning for survival and developing a strategy for the future. Randall Stevens of AVAIL and Eric Hauck of MEP Equine Solutions will talk about steps they are taking to continue to move forward.
description:
The COVID-19 shutdown has impacted virtually every aspect of our personal and business lives. What if you have been pushing your startup for several years, gaining customer traction, attracting investors and planning for that hockey stick growth curve then COVID-19 hits.


Find out what two local entrepreneurs have done in planning for survival and developing a strategy for the future. Randall Stevens of AVAIL and Eric Hauck of MEP Equine Solutions will talk about steps they are taking to continue to move forward.


To Join the Meetup:

Register in advance for this meeting:

https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tZAsdOuuqjgpFest32xlOGWCmUobzvFErQ


After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the meeting.


About Randall:

Randall Stevens is an AEC industry veteran with 25+ years of software development, sales and management experience. Randall founded ArchVision in 1991, a software development firm specializing in 3D graphics and content management technology for the design industry. Randall offers a unique combination of expertise in software and graphics technology, coupled with a background and degree in architecture. Randall is the inventor of the software technology Rich Photorealistic Content (RPC) currently being used by AEC customers in more than 100 countries.


Randall was also a founder of technology companies Mersive Technologies and Punndit. Most recently Randall led product development of the AVAIL software platform, a fresh approach to the AEC market's content management challenges. Randall is now CEO of AVAIL.


Randall received his B.A. from the University Of Kentucky College Of Architecture, served as an adjunct faculty member at the College of Design at the University of Kentucky from 1991-2007 and currently serves on the College of Design Advocacy Board. He currently teaches entrepreneurship at the University of Kentucky College of Business. Randall chairs the Advisory Board for the University of Kentucky Innovation Network for Entrepreneurial Thinking (iNET) and is on the Board of Directors for the Kentucky Governor's School for Entrepreneurs.


Randall owns and operates Base110 and Base163 housing central Kentucky creative and technology companies in over 25K square feet of office and co-working space in Lexington, Kentucky. He is a frequent speaker and lecturer on technology and entrepreneurship.


About Eric:

Eric Hauck has been an entrepreneur of over 30 years leading various types of startups including biotech medical devices to consumer electronics with very successful outcomes for investors. He has served in C-level positions for several mid-size companies including Somfy/Damart a French fortune 500 company in Europe. He currently serves as Founder and President of MEP Equine Solutions, the developer of a revolutionary fecal egg count system, called “Parasight” currently being commercialized. www.parasightsystem.com


Eric is an angel investor with the Bluegrass Angels located in Lexington KY. Eric also serves as an Adjunct Professor at the University of Kentucky’s Gatton Business College where he teaches a Capstone MBA course for entrepreneurs. Additionally, He serves as a Board member in several companies including two health science start-ups and one turnaround located in the KY area. Eric holds a BA in Biochemistry from the University of Arizona and an MBA and MS in Science and Technology Commercialization from Northeastern University located in Boston MA. He is the proud father of 4, is happily married to his wife Barbie, and loves to race cars when he has time.

title: WHEN YOU "CAN'T" WRITE. ESPECIALLY WHEN YOU HAVE THE TIME.
brief_description: How to stay connected to your writing and creativity during lengthy "writer's blocks."
description:
WHEN YOU "CAN'T" WRITE. ESPECIALLY WHEN YOU HAVE THE TIME.


In this online session we will discuss:

+ How to stay connected to your writing and creativity during lengthy "writer's blocks."

+ How to recognize the gifts of the writing pause. How to use these necessary periods to your advantage, guilt- and fear-free.

+ How to emerge with a different, bolder, more vibrant work than ever before.


I'll offer three identical sessions:

+ 4/22 at 11am

+ 4/25 at 2pm

+ 4/27 at 6pm


The sessions are free, with a $5.00 suggested donation. To sign up, simply send an email to accents.publishing@gmail.com indicating which session you'd like to join.


A few of my thoughts on writing/not writing from my book Bird on a Window Sill (Publishing House Signs, 2017):

+ If you don't write when you don't have time for it, you won't write when you do have time for it.

+ Writing can be seasonal. Liking your own writing can be seasonal too.

+ The Four Stages of Writer's Block

Stage I. I want to write, but I can't

Stage II. I have to write, but I can't

Stage III. I don't want to write, but I have to

Stage IV. I don't have time for writing ... and honestly, I don't feel like writing.

+ To write, you need more courage than time.

+ At the end of your life it won't matter how much you've written, but how much you've changed.


Thank you!

Katerina Stoykova

Senior Editor

Accents Publishing

title: Experience in Amateur Hour
brief_description: Join us in celebrating the great achievement of over 50 of our students in Digital Media Design and traditional Bachelor of Arts in Art Studio
description: We would like to announce the launch of the University of Kentucky School of Art and Visual Studies Digital Senior Exhibition “Experience in Amateur Hour.” This exhibition—to be viewed at https://ukyseniorshow.cargo.site/ —is a presentation of capstone research which began in classrooms and studios and finished online via zoom meetings—with work completed in students' kitchens, bedrooms, and living rooms across the nation. Over 50 students have participated, earning a Bachelor of Science in Digital Media Design or a Bachelor of Arts in Art Studio, respectively. The exhibit will be available for viewing for the next year. Join us in celebrating the great achievements of our students and their exceptionally beautiful and accomplished work.

title: Intro to Paint 3D
admission_fee: $40 per person for the four-session class
brief_description: Learn the basics of this imaginative 3D drawing program.
description:
Paint 3D comes standard on all Windows 10 operating systems. If you're running Windows 10 - you should already have it. (Check to be sure.) This fun upgrade to the original Paint program adds the fun of three-dimensional design, allowing you to create and view images from multiple perspectives and angles. Kids will have a blast creating their own 3D monsters, buildings, landscapes and more in this four-session online class.

 Students will meet with instructor Brandon Long via Zoom for four, one-hour sessions, learning the basic functionality of the program through a series of projects. The age parameters for this class are flexible. Children need to be comfortable with basic computer navigation - understanding how to select objects on a screen, click on icons, manipulate a mouse or track pad, etc.

 Please note that Paint3D is only available for the Windows 10 operating system so check your system compatibility before registering. If you have any questions, contact brandon@artcenterky.org.

title: Starry Night Studio: Sweet Bessie
brief_description: Learn to paint this fetching bovine through a two-hour guided class.
description:
The Art Center's popular Starry Night Studio program is BACK - now, with social distancing!

Learn to paint this fetching bovine through a two-hour guided class. Sweet Bessie brings a touch to of whimsy to any room. Your instructor will lead you, step-by-step, from blank canvas to finished masterpiece. 

Several days before the scheduled class, students will pick up a supply kit that includes their canvas, brushes, and paint. Class will be facilitated via live Zoom instruction, allowing for interaction between students and instructor. Invite some friends to join you, grab your favorite beverage and get ready to paint!

 This class is open to artists of all ages. Kids may need a supportive adult to help them (but said adult does not need to register separately).

title: Live Virtual Tour of Josephine Sculpture Park
brief_description: Join us for our first-ever Virtual Lunch with the Arts with the fabulous folks at Josephine Sculpture Park in Frankfort.
description:
For the past 10 years, the Art Center of the Bluegrass has hosted Lunch with the Arts on the 3rd Wednesday of each month, inviting artists across a wide spectrum of artistic genres to share their work and their passion. Big thanks to Stuart Powell Ford Lincoln Mazda and Direct Experience in Artistic Living, Inc. for sponsoring our Lunch with the Arts programs!


On May 27th, we will host our first-ever Virtual Lunch with the Arts, thanks to the fabulous folks at Josephine Sculpture Park in Frankfort.

Josephine Sculpture Park is dedicated to connecting the community with the land through the arts. They provide free arts education and creative experiences while conserving the beauty of Kentucky’s native, rural landscape.

Melanie Van Houten, Executive Director of Josephine Sculpture Park, will give a LIVE introduction to the park - its history, mission, and programming (plus a tour of the grounds!) - via Facebook Live, starting at 12pm.


In order to participate in this event, just RSVP "going" to the Facebook event, then tune in for the Facebook live stream on May 27th.

Arts organizations everywhere are suffering due to the COVID-19 closures. JSP and the Art Center are no exception. Both organizations are currently closed to the public. Please consider making donations to these organizations using the links below:

www.artcenterky.org

www.josephinesculpturepark.org

description:

title: WEKU Concert Encore Broadcast Series: CARMEN
brief_description: WEKU and Lexington Philharmonic bring Symphony Performance to Kentuckians During COVID-19 Crisis
description:
CARMEN

FRIDAY, MAY 29 @ 8PM - WEKU Classical (online)

SUNDAY, MAY 31 @ 8PM - WEKU 88.9 (on your radio!)

Originally Performed: February 10, 2017

SCOTT TERRELL, Conductor


GRANADOS - Tres danzas españolas

PIAZZOLLA - Aconcagua: Concerto for Bandoneón 

Héctor Del Curto, bandoneón

PIAZZOLLA - Oblivion

BiIZET arr. José Serebrier - Carmen Symphony in 12 Scenes


WEKU and Lexington Philharmonic bring Symphony Performance to Kentuckians During COVID-19 Crisis. 


As the longtime broadcast partner of the Lexington Philharmonic, public radio station WEKU 88.9 and LexPhil have agreed to broadcast five encore LexPhil performances every two weeks through the end of June. 


While the Lexington Philharmonic’s 2019/2020 Season has been cancelled, the WEKU encore broadcasts are one way WEKU and the Lexington Philharmonic are helping Kentuckians connect to the music of their orchestra safely at home. The orchestra has also developed an online platform titled LexPhil Living Room, to share musician performance videos, education videos and resources for families at home, and other national and international music resources to provide the community with ways to keep classical music a part of life at home. The WEKU encore broadcast dates and links to listen will also be hosted at the Lexington Philharmonic website. “In times like these, it is human nature to want to gather and support each other. This is a different way of gathering for a concert, yet one that is comfortingly familiar,” says Allison Kaiser, LexPhil Executive Director. “WEKU FM has been an important partner to LexPhil for decades and now is a perfect time to introduce additional ways of sharing the resources of this dynamic partnership. We are very grateful for the generosity of spirit, time and commitment from WEKU.” 


WEKU encore broadcasts of Lexington Philharmonic concerts will be aired on both WEKU Classical, and WEKU 88.9. Following broadcast on WEKU Classical, listeners will have two weeks to tune in online to listen to the concert stream.

title: The Time Machine - H.G. Wells
description:
Time Machine - H.G. Wells

Performed at the Woodford Theatre 4/2018

Recorded and Produced by Paul R Manning


It is always free to listen, but to help us pay for licensing fees please use the "Get Tickets" link on click on the "Support Backstage" button on our homepage at https://www.adventuretheatreky.com


Message from Paul: It is interesting to note that H.G. Wells published The Time Machine in 1895. Wells was the first person to coin the phrase Time Machine. This radio play is a closer adaptation than the 1960 and 2002 Movies. Wells did not have a concept of nuclear annihilation featured in those movies.


Voice Cast:


Filby (Narrator/Friend) - Wesley Jay Akers

John (Time Traveler) - Carmen Geraci

Samuel/Recording 1 (Friend) - Johnathan Watson

Colin/Recording 2 (Friend) - Dave Dampier

James/Recording 3 (Friend) - John Lynaugh

Mrs. Watchett (Housekeeper) -Gina Scott Lynaugh

Meendo (Young Voice)- Emery Grimm

Eloi #1/Weena (Young Voice)- Mallory Grimm


Sound Effects - Paul R Manning

Sound - Clifton Grimm

title: Virtual pre-show auditions - Ballet Under the Stars
brief_description: This year we will be holding virtual auditions. This year's pre-show theme is Princess Vignettes II.
description:
We are hopeful we will be able to hold Ballet Under the Stars as scheduled. However, it remains to be seen what reopening phase we will be in regarding mass gatherings and social distancing recommendations in August. We are preparing as though it’s happening, knowing there are no guarantees or that it may look very different from how we usually do things. We are working on numerous program adaptations and contingency plans in the event we can offer the program with restrictions.


With that in mind, this year we will be holding virtual auditions. This year's pre-show theme is Princess Vignettes II. To submit a virtual audition or for more information about the audition process and show contingency plans, head over to our website ➡️ lexingtonky.gov/ballet-under-stars-auditions


Deadline to submit an application is May 20.


This year is the 31st anniversary for Ballet Under the Stars, a show that has become one of central Kentucky’s most beloved events. This year’s pre-show production will be Princess Vignettes II and will be held at Woodland Park in Lexington, July 30- August 2.


The pre-show is a wonderful chance for young dancers from all area dance schools to come together in Kentucky’s premier outdoor ballet event. This is truly a community production and an excellent opportunity to showcase the young talent of central Kentucky as well as the quality of dance instruction available to our area’s youth. In addition, all of the dance schools represented by pre-show participants will receive promotions throughout the event as each child’s name and place of instruction will be included in the program.

brief_description: While the name of the band and even the nice suits suggest a rockabilly sound, the band is quite diverse, as their tight set demonstrates.
description:
LIVE STREAM AT 8:00pm EST through Facebook Live!

°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°∙°

NP Presley & The Ghost of Jesse Garon

While the name of the band and even the nice suits suggest a rockabilly sound, the band is quite diverse, as their tight set demonstrates. They segue easily from rockabilly to punk to rock 'n roll to even gospel with tight harmonies on several songs. Keys and sax slide in around the music and the drums keep a strong beat going, making the crowd move along. They are up there preaching, telling the crowd their story, and making sure it drives home. They want their crowd to be in it with them.

title: KAC: Budgeting During a Global Pandemic
brief_description: The Kentucky Arts Council is hosting a live webinar via ZOOM with financial expert Elaine Grogan Luttrull, CPA and financial therapist, of Minerva Financial Arts.
description:
The Kentucky Arts Council is hosting a live webinar via ZOOM with financial expert Elaine Grogan Luttrull, CPA and financial therapist, of Minerva Financial Arts. Elaine has been a popular presenter at the previous Kentucky Creative Industry Summit. The webinar is free but does require preregistration. It will include topics for both individual artists and nonprofit arts organizations.


We know financial planning is hard right now, but it is still a worthwhile exercise and can provide some reassurance in these uncertain times. It’s OK to ask for help, and Elaine will provide information to help you plan. In this webinar, she will review scenarios to help organizations and individuals plan for the ongoing pandemic and the eventual recovery. As part of the webinar, we will:

  • Identify three to four scenarios to assist in financial planning.
  • Describe the impact on revenues from various sources.
  • Strategize for solving financial shortfalls.

When: May 7, 2020, 4 p.m. Eastern

Register in advance for this meeting: https://bit.ly/2KJ2twy

After registering, you will receive a confirmation email with information about joining the meeting.


This webinar is part of the Kentucky Arts Council’s COVID-19 response efforts. We need your assistance in distributing this information to reach a wide audience. Please share with others who may be interested.

title: 48 Hours of Neukölln
brief_description: 48 hours of Neukölln is an international arts festival that invites hundreds of artists from Germany and around the world to exhibit work in spaces around the Berlin district of Neukölln, an area settled by Bohemians from Czechoslovakia in the 1800s. Like many events and programs, 48 hours of Neukölln had to pivot from an on-site art encounter to a virtual exhibition. Featured in this year’s event, among the over 200 participating international artists, are faculty and graduate students from the University of Kentucky’s school of Art / Visual Studies. The main festival page can be found here: https://48-stunden-neukoelln.de/de/festival/homepage
description:
48 hours of Neukölln is an international arts festival that invites hundreds of artists from Germany and around the world to exhibit work in spaces around the Berlin district of Neukölln, an area settled by Bohemians from Czechoslovakia in the 1800s. Like many events and programs, 48 hours of Neukölln had to pivot from an on-site art encounter to a virtual exhibition. Featured in this year’s event, among the over 200 participating international artists, are faculty and graduate students from the University of Kentucky’s school of Art / Visual Studies. The main festival page can be found here: https://48-stunden-neukoelln.de/de/festival/homepage



As group of ten in total, we each created an online gallery using the German company Kunstmatrix 3D online gallery platform. Here is a list of artists participating and their galleries: 


Becky Alley:  https://www.kunstmatrix.com/en/becky-alley

Marika Christofides:  https://artspaces.kunstmatrix.com/en/exhibition/1291527/its-my-party-by-marika-christofides
