title: Chamber Music Lex - Youtube
brief_description: Video documentations of Chamber Music Lex highlights
description:
Chamber Music Lex's mission is to present high-quality chamber music in central Kentucky in a variety of environments that fosters greater appreciation of the chamber music repertoire and regular community engagement, performed by a mixture of world class and local musicians!


We operate two musical programs for the Lexington community:

1.) a multi-day music festival in the heart of the famed Bluegrass region of Kentucky in late August. The Chamber Music Festival of Lexington serves central Kentucky with multiple concerts and educational programming featuring renowned and emerging artists.


2.) The Lexington Chamber Orchestra is a small ensemble that produces 3-4 classical music programs throughout the year by local musicians under the artistic direction of Maestro Jan Pellant.

title: Da Poetry Lounge: Largest weekly Open mic in America
brief_description: Come visit us next Tuesday and be part of what has become the largest weekly open mic in America.
description:
Da Poetry Lounge is a poetry venue at the Greenway Court Theatre, Los Angeles. We have been in operation since 1998. 


The ultimate goal of DPL is to create a communal space for people to be heard. We celebrate poetry in all forms, and welcome all those who are courageous enough to share their stories or are willing to support others that do. 


Come visit us next Tuesday and be part of what has become the largest weekly open mic in America. Sign up lists are posted at noon the day of on Instagram, first come first served. 3rd Tuesdays are slam nights, NOT open mic.


Follow @da_poetry_lounge on Instagram page for information about online spoken lit workshops too!

https://www.instagram.com/da_poetry_lounge/


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT

Cash App $DPLTuesdays

Venmo @DPLTuesdays

title: Bourbon & Poetry Festival
brief_description: The inaugural Bourbon & Poetry Festival a live-streamed event hosted by the Affrilachian Poets Featuring  Mitchell Douglas, Stephanie Pruitt, Bianca Spriggs, Frank X Walker, and Asha French.
description:
The inaugural Bourbon & Poetry Festival a live-streamed event hosted by the Affrilachian Poets Featuring Mitchell Douglas, Stephanie Pruitt, Bianca Spriggs, Frank X Walker, and Asha French. This event will be streamed live on the Affrilachian Poets Facebook group page. #Bourbonandpoetryfestival2020


Guest Poets:

Nandi Comer is the author of Tapping Out (Triquarterly/Northwestern) and the chapbook American Family: A Syndrome (Finishing Line Press). She is a Cave Canem Fellow, a Callaloo Fellow, and a 2019 Kresge Arts in Detroit Fellow. Her poems and essays have appeared in The Offing, Epiphany Magazine, The Metro Times, Crab Orchard Review, Pluck! and numerous anthologies. She directs the Allied Media Projects Speakers Bureau and is a founding member of the collective, Detroit Lit. To purchase a copy of Tapping Out from the publisher, use the 25% off coupon code COMER25.


Shauna Morgan author of the chapbook Fear of Dogs & Other Animals (Central Square Press), is a poet and scholar from a rural district in Clarendon, Jamaica. An Associate Professor of creative writing and Africana literature at Howard University in Washington, D.C., she recently moved to Lexington, Kentucky’s East End Artist Village with her husband and children. Shauna has published poetry in A Gathering Together, ProudFlesh: New Afrikan Journal of Culture, Politics & Consciousness, Pluck! The Journal of Affrilachian Arts & Culture, and elsewhere. Her critical work has appeared in the CLA Journal, Journal of Postcolonial Writing, and South Atlantic Review.


Bro. Yao (Hoke S. Glover III) is a poet and non-fiction writer living in Lanham, MD. His work has been published in Crab Orchard Review, African-American Review, Ploughshares, Beltway Quarterly, and other journals. He teaches at Bowie State University in the Department of Language, Literature, and Cultural Studies. His second book of poetry, One Shoe Marching Towards Heaven, will be published by Africa World Press in Summer 2020. He is currently working on a book of essays called The Wuhan Soundtrack based on his experience living in Wuhan, China.


Honorée Fanonne Jeffers is the author of five books of poetry, most recently, The Age of Phillis (Wesleyan, 2020), based upon the life and times of Phillis Wheatley Peters, a formerly enslaved person who was the first African American woman to publish a book. In addition, Honorée is the author of a forthcoming novel, The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois (Harper, 2021). She has received fellowships from the Bread Loaf Writers Conference, the National Endowment for the Arts, and the Witter Bynner Foundation through the Library of Congress, among others. Honorée is a Professor of English at the University of Oklahoma.

title: Open to Interpretation: Art Center of the Bluegrass
brief_description: Open to Interpretation is an invitational exhibit of abstract artwork by the region’s best abstract artists.
description:
Open to Interpretation is an invitational exhibit of abstract artwork by the region’s best abstract artists. The exhibit showcases non-objective abstract art, which means that the artist wasn’t specifically trying to recreate an image. You might be tempted to look for trees, buildings, or people in these paintings, but for most of the artists in this exhibit – that is not the intent. The artist may be trying to capture a mood, a feeling, or exploring just what paint can do.

You can visit the exhibit in person through August 14. The Art Center is open Tuesday through Friday, 11am to 7pm and Saturdays 10am to 5pm. Please read our updated COVID-19 policies before visiting.

If you aren’t able to see the exhibit in person, please enjoy the virtual exhibit, available on the Art Center's website!

The artwork in this show is for sale. Size and price details are included in the captions of the image thumbnails in the virtual gallery on the website. Click on an image to see a larger version, along with details. To purchase a piece, please call 859.236.4054.

title: New Music by Social-Distancing Composers
brief_description: Join us on Facebook LIVE for an evening of world premieres written in the midst of a global pandemic
description:
Join us on Facebook LIVE for an evening of world premieres written in the midst of a global pandemic! After countless disappointing cancellations in the performing arts, it became imperative that we find ways to keep generating contemporary art for the public. These composers were kind enough to supply their creativity!


In solidarity with working artists affected by the COVID-19 crisis all over the US, please show these composers your support by tuning in to the livestream ON THIS EVENT PAGE on FRIDAY, May 8th at 7:30PM or watching later on and sharing with your friends! Featured composers include Jonathan Posthuma, William Peacock, Justine Koontz, and many more.

title: Art Center of the Bluegrass Virtual Exhibits
brief_description: We’re excited to host a series of virtual exhibits this spring so that we can continue to showcase and celebrate the artists – both emerging and established – that make our region a thriving center for the arts.
description:
Our building is closed to the public, but artists innovate – it’s what we do. The world needs more art right now, not less. We’re excited to host a series of virtual exhibits this spring so that we can continue to showcase and celebrate the artists – both emerging and established – that make our region a thriving center for the arts.


Connections

Artists working in any medium were invited to submit images of work that fit the theme of “connection” as they interpret it.

Click here to see the virtual exhibit.


Kids Art Show of the Bluegrass

This exhibit had just opened in March when the COVID-19 virus shut down the building. Check out a sampling of the fantastic work submitted by students throughout the southern Bluegrass region.

Click here to view the virtual exhibit.

title: Vincent and Theo - Online Movie Discussion
brief_description: Watch the movie (available to rent from Amazon Prime) then join us for a discussion
description:
Looking for a new movie recommendation during quarantine? We suggest the 1990 production of Theo and Vincent.

Watch the movie (available to rent from Amazon Prime) then join us for a discussion on Friday, May 8th. To request an invitation to the online meeting, please email kate@artcenterky.org.

During his lifetime, Vincent Van Gogh (Tim Roth) has no greater champion of his work than his devoted brother, Theo (Paul Rhys). As an art gallery owner, Theo pushes for the recognition that Van Gogh's masterpieces deserve, only to meet with abject failure. While Van Gogh struggles with obscurity and mental illness, Theo faces serious financial difficulties due to poor sales. Eventually, both the Van Gogh brothers begin falling apart over the reality of their unrealized dreams.

title: Here Today...
brief_description: This is an ambitious statewide community project to create a unique photographic portrait which captures the spirit, mood, hopes, fears, and feelings of Kentuckians as we continue to deal with the Coronavirus outbreak.
description:
​Arts Connect is pleased to introduce: Here Today... a photo essay of Kentucky during covid-19. This is an ambitious statewide community project to create a unique photographic portrait which captures the spirit, mood, hopes, fears, and feelings of Kentuckians as we continue to deal with the Coronavirus outbreak.


Here Today... will be a snapshot of Kentucky as we have been going through these uncertain times, creating a collective narrative of our State which will reflect the resilience, bravery, humor and sadness, creativity and kindness as well as the very real human tragedy but also the presence of irrepressible hope.  Originally limited to images that included people, this project has been expanded to include animals as well as scenes or a situation that specifically relates to this pandemic period. 


You are invited to submit a photographic image taken during these times that responds to but is not limited to one of these themes:

  • Helpers and Heroes
  • Your New Normal
  • Love in the time of Covid-19 (Acts of Kindness)
  • Humor as a form of Healing
  • Where would we be without ...


One hundred shortlisted portraits will be featured in a virtual exhibition on this website and a selection of images will be shown in a physical location later.


This program has a $10 per entry fee - 40% of which will be donated to the Artist Relief Trust that has been created to provide rapid response microgrants to Kentucky artists who are experiencing financial difficulties meeting basic needs during this difficult time.

It is open to all ages and abilities. Images can be taken on phones or with cameras. Each image will be assessed on the strength of the emotional experience it conveys rather than its photographic quality or technical expertise. ​Photographs must be taken in Kentucky. Entries are not limited to one per person - multiple submissions are permitted.


An Overall Winner will be selected and a cash prize of $500 will be awarded to the photographer of the image that best captures the spirit of Kentucky during COVID-19. Additionally, our online voting community will cast votes for the "People's Choice" award, and the winning photographer will be awarded a $200 cash prize.

title: PUBLISHING, PROMOTING AND MARKETING YOUR POETRY BOOK
brief_description: Best practices before, during, after, and long after the book is out.
description:
PUBLISHING, PROMOTING AND MARKETING YOUR POETRY BOOK


Publishing, promoting and marketing your poetry book. Best practices before, during, after, and long after the book is out. In this session we will talk about transforming ourselves from poets into authors. What can we expect? We will learn about the courage and stamina needed for self-promotion. How to make the process more efficient, effective and enjoyable. How to make the most of the publication of your book. 

Besides the author of award-winning poetry books, Katerina Stoykova is the senior editor of Accents publishing, where she has selected, edited, and published over 80 poetry books.  


Free, with $5 suggested donation 


There will be three identical 60 minute sessions

+ 5/23 at 2pm

+ 5/25 at 6pm

+ 5/26 at 10am 


To sign up, send an email to accents.publishing@gmail.com

title: 2020 UK Digital Media Blast! Quarantine Edition!
brief_description: UK student work - film festival format you can all enjoy in the comfort of your homes this semester. Please share freely and widely with family and friends
description: Every semester the School of Art & Visual Studies presents a juried festival of Digital Media projects our students have created in various classes, including Lens Arts, Digital Video, Animation and more. We always show this on the 'big screen' in a theater, but this year it is not possible because of the mandated social distancing orders. We decided to present the Digital Media Blast! in a film festival format you can all enjoy in the comfort of your homes this semester. Please share freely and widely with family and friends. There are several categories to check out that include work from freshmen through to seniors. Please feel free to leave comments for our students! Make sure to expand the info below each category if you want to skip ahead to a particular student's work. Congratulations to everyone who made the cut into the 2020 Digital Media Blast! Quarantine Edition! Enjoy!

title: Lessons with The Arboretum
brief_description: Join The Arboretum for Facebook live lessons relating to plants, biology, and Kentucky ecology every Thursday at 10 am.
description: Join The Arboretum for Facebook live lessons relating to plants, biology, and Kentucky ecology every Thursday at 10 am. Each lesson will last about 30 minutes and will be geared toward families but anyone who wants to learn is welcome. This next lesson on Thursday, May 14th will be about leaves and trees. Learn about the basics of tree identification through leaves and go on a short tour of our favorite native Kentucky trees.

title: Shelter in Place
brief_description: Shelter in Place, is a response to these events from the eyes of current and recent digital photography students from the University of Kentucky’s School of Art & Visual Studies department.
description:
5.20.20-5.30.20


*digital viewing below, in-person viewing by appointment only*

Email info@parachutefactorylex.com to arrange.


We, as well as the rest of the world, will look back on this time period and reflect upon how we reacted and responded to events of the Covid-19 outbreak: how it affected our economy, our country, and how we saw each other. The group exhibition, Shelter in Place, is a response to these events from the eyes of current and recent digital photography students from the University of Kentucky’s School of Art & Visual Studies department. With the help of their instructor, artists made digital photography works representing how they are dealing with the pandemic experience. Whether it be the artists’ growing respect for healthcare workers, their self isolation, or even the hobbies that help them escape the stresses of modern life, each piece reflects this. 


It is with great pride that I share a show that was made during one of the most challenging semesters for my fellow educators' careers, as well as our students' careers. Through social distancing, video conferences, and file sharing, we put together a collective body of work that shows off our communities' concerns and pride. We hope that this work will be looked back upon, years from now, as a unique example of artists responding to their locale, highlighting our community’s unique experience. 


Instructor:

James Robert Southard

Senior Lecturer of Photography, School of Art & Visual Studies, University of Kentucky

title: Colored Pencil Drawing
brief_description: In this four session class, instructor Brandon Long will teach you how to enrich your drawings with colored pencils as we learn to create realistic shading, blend colors, add texture, and more.
description:
Combine drawing with COLOR! It's like painting, but without the mess.

In this four session class, instructor Brandon Long will teach you how to enrich your drawings with colored pencils as we learn to create realistic shading, blend colors, add texture, and more.

Students will need to supply their own materials. You can use any colored pencils you like, but we suggest a 24 color Prismacolor Premier set (easily purchasable online). For this intro class, plain white computer paper is fine to use.

Your $30 registration fee includes 16" x 20" stretched canvas, paint, and a set of Art Center brushes to use. (Please bring the brushes back after class!) Your supplies can be picked up from the Art Center on Wednesday, June 3rd or Thursday, June 4th.

title: Pen and Ink Drawing

description:
Pen and ink - It's not just for calligraphy. In this four-session class, you'll learn how to incorporate pen and ink into your drawings. We'll cover shading and texture techniques as well as learn how to use water and a brush to do ink washes for dramatic watercolor-esque effects.

Class will be conducted via live Zoom session with the instructor.

Required Materials (linked to our recommendations)

  • Watercolor or mixed media paper
  • Pen and ink set
  • Chinese calligraphy brush set

title: A Mask on the Mountains: Dimensions of COVID in Appalachia
brief_description: Seven audio documentaries produced by the Appalachian Media Institute
description:
This year, Appalshop invited seven young people to produce audio pieces through the Summer Documentary Institute, all on the same subject — COVID-19. Their work aired in July on WMMT 88.7 FM, and the reception has already been tremendous.

These works are now available to stream:


Two Branches: Sports vs. a Pandemic by Sean Hall

You're meeting so many people. You don't know if they have coronavirus. So when you go to practice, you think 'Should I even be here? Am I going to hurt somebody?

Behind Closed Doors (During a Pandemic) by Jamie Shepherd

We heard from survivors, "I've been so isolated for such a period of time and no one else has laid eyes on me that either I leave right now and get help, or I'm going to get killed."

Foster Care in a Pandemic World by Hannah Adams

With no social workers going in, you can't see what's going on in that home.

A Prepaid Call for Help: Prisons in a Pandemic by Madison Buchanan

I have yet to have access to chemicals to sanitize my cell, nor to have my ill-fitting sneeze guard washed regularly ... I am constantly subjected to exposure.

Symptom of Slavery: Racism in Healthcare During a Pandemic by Abby Enfuse

Obviously there's going to be a disparity in [COVID-19] treatment and testing because that that happens where? In hospitals. Where are hospitals? Not in black neighborhoods.

College Students in a Pandemic by Nikole Lee

When I think about when I had to leave college, that's what I think about: it sucked.

 Cancelled Culture by Alyssa Helton

A whole string of cancelations of various events and gatherings and get-togethers ... it was like a string of dominoes falling.

title: Cross-Training for Artists - Online Class with Supplies Provided
brief_description: Through a series of four classes, we’ll explore a variety of artistic media, including drawing, painting, sculpture, collage, and printmaking.
description:
Every great athlete trains in other sports in order to strengthen their skills. Artists should do the same! Through a series of four classes, we’ll explore a variety of artistic media, including drawing, painting, sculpture, collage, and printmaking.

Class meets twice a week for two weeks: Mondays and Wednesdays, 1:30pm to 3pm, June 1, 3, 8 & 10. The $70 registration fee includes all supplies. Register online at www.artcenterky.org/kids-classes

title: Kids Drawing (Online Class for Ages 8 to 11)
brief_description: Learn the fundamentals of drawing by learning a different core technique each session.
description:
Learn the fundamentals of drawing by learning a different core technique each session. Instructor Brandon Long will provide live technique demonstrations (facilitated via Zoom) and assign drawing exercises for students to complete during the class period.

The only supplies you need are a pencil, a good eraser, a ruler or straightedge, and blank white paper.

This class is designed for students ages 8 to 11. Students slightly older or younger are welcome at the discretion of parents.

title: Awesome Inc Web Developer Bootcamp Demo Day
brief_description: Demo Day is the public's first glimpse into the results of a 500+ hour journey into software development. Hiring programmers? Join us.
description:
In February, a small group of aspiring software developers began a 500+ hour journey of intense, hands-on learning in Awesome Inc's Web Developer Bootcamp. On Thursday, June 4th, our Spring 2020 students will be presenting their final projects, full-stack web applications, to a group of tech company executives, local software developers, and other members of the Lexington-area technology community.

Each member of the Bootcamp cohort will give a brief presentation of his or her final project, followed by an opportunity to get to know our students and experience their web applications hands-on (In a safe, social distancing sort of way. You know, via the Internet).


Special note: this will be a live, online event. Video conference details will be provided after registration.


The first program of its kind in Central Kentucky, the goal of the Web Developer Bootcamp is to help professionals transition into a new career in software development. Is your organization planning to hire? This is a great opportunity for local companies to recruit local tech talent to support their growth, especially as tech moves beyond its own borders and becomes a bigger part of healthcare, manufacturing, finance, and beyond. This is also a great opportunity to check out the Bootcamp program if you are interested in a career in technology.

title: Street Art for Kinds (Online Class Ages 8 to 11)
brief_description: Get an introduction to the creative world of street art in this all-new online class with Brandon Long.
description:
Get an introduction to the creative world of street art in this all-new online class with Brandon Long. In keeping with the realities of social distancing, we've designed this curriculum with a focus on your community. We will be creating art for your backyard, and your street, whether it be in the heart of the city or on a rural farm. We will study the art of other great street artists and make our own versions that are safe and appropriate for your young artist and their neighborhood.  

What can you expect from a take-home art class?

  • A range of engaging art lessons, facilitated by a professional artist LIVE via Zoom.
  • All necessary supplies for all lessons.
  • Access to online resources like videos and activities that tie into the class theme and enhance the class experience..

title: Institute 193: Participation in not cancelled
brief_description: not cancelled’s Southern U.S. exhibition is now live and runs from May 23 to 30. Institute 193 is featuring nine works by Lina Tharsing
description:
not cancelled’s Southern U.S. exhibition is now live and runs from May 23 to 30. Institute 193 is featuring nine works by Lina Tharsing, eight of which are available for sale via the “inquire” button.


Lina Tharsing is a painter and photographer whose work explores the harmonies between the two mediums, and their ability to capture and alter the natural world. Often using photographs as initial reference points, her paintings transpose these snapshots to painted studies that invite a closer look at scenes of the poetic within the prosaic. Photographic flattening lends itself to painted play with dimensionality, pattern, and light, ever so often slipping the viewer into mystical or transportive realms as memory comes to predominantly inform the image.


The core of Tharsing’s work is based in the natural world, in its manipulations and interconnectedness to our daily lives — as food, still life, study, or encompassing environment. Soccer goals become sculptural portals to other places and grass tangled and woven into a chain-link fence becomes a tapestry of layers in quietly observed moments. For Tharsing, the coexistence of the natural world and the built environment deserve considerate attention, as either one can be transformed into something otherworldly through the other.


Lina Tharsing lives and works in Kentucky. Recent solo and group exhibitions include: 21c Museum Hotel (2019), the University of Kentucky Art Museum, the Lexington Art League (2019), The Food Connection at the University of Kentucky (2018), the Elaine de Kooning House (2018), and Atlanta Contemporary (2017). In 2012, she was named a superstar of Southern art by Oxford American. She has been featured in Hyperallergic, ARTnews, Burnaway, Whitehot Magazine, Garden & Gun Magazine, The Atlanta Journal Constitution, The Journal, and Booooooom.

title: Live At Base110 with Alioune Guisse
brief_description: Premier Live at Base110 a series exploring music, culture, and conversations about art & community
description:
This Saturday we premier Live at Base110 a series exploring music, culture, and conversations about art & community.


Join us for a virtual discussion with the award-winning vocalist Alioune Guisse about his international travels, partnership with Green Room Exchange, and recent recording expedition in Senegal.


We will be joined by Lexington’s Lee Carol and Connie Milligan to talk about their collaboration, discoveries while traveling, and the project that is unfolding during the global shutdown.


His father, Amadou Guisse, was founder and lead singer of the Fulani Yela. The first group dedicated to the promotion and evolution of the music of the Fulani people of northern Senegal. Baaba Maal made his debut with this group.

title: Out of Hand with Ed McClanahan Kickstarter
brief_description: Institute 193 has launched a Kickstarter to fund our first unbound publication and a gift of McClanahan's original drawings to the University of Kentucky Art Museum.
description:
Institute 193 is publishing, for the first time, an unbound publication consisting of 13 drawings made by the artist and writer, Ed McClanahan, accompanied by an essay written by Elizabeth Glass, our Lexington gallery director. In addition to the creation of this portable publication, we are creating a tote bag with the aim of funding a purchase of the original works which would then be donated to the University of Kentucky Art Museum. We feel that these drawings should be kept together to be enjoyed, studied, shared, and preserved for future generations.


As a Kentucky native, Ed McClanahan's work deserves a space in the UK Art Museum's permanent collection, and his drawings would join artworks made by other acclaimed literary figures including Kurt Vonnegut and Wayne Koestenbaum.


The mission of the University of Kentucky Art Museum is to promote the understanding and appreciation of art to enhance the quality of life for people of Kentucky through collecting, exhibiting, preserving and interpreting outstanding works of visual art from all cultures.

title: The Importance of Being Earnest - Radio Encore!
brief_description: Social distancing and closed venues are no match for the wit and whimsy of Oscar Wilde
description:
AthensWest has revived our 2018 hit production of

THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST (with the entire original cast!) and adapted it for presentation on 91.3 WUKY Radio. Tune in on your radio or smart home device Tuesday, May 26, from 7-9pm and stay tuned afterwards for a live, post-show Zoom chat featuring some of our cast and crew. We will also be live-Tweeting the event, so be sure to follow #AthensWildeWest. WUKY will feature a repeat broadcast on Sunday, May 31, 1-3pm - so you have two chances to tune in!

Go here for more information, including how to Zoom with us! https://www.wuky.org/importance-being-ernest-airs-wuky#stream/0


Social distancing and closed venues are no match for the wit and whimsy of Oscar Wilde, whose classic comedy THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST has endured for 125 years, and will more than survive our current pandemic!


The play follows Algernon and Jack, two respectable London gentlemen, who use every trick in the book (except the truth) to outwit the other and find true love with their respective paramours, Cecily and Gwendolen.


THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST, by Oscar Wilde, was directed by Trent Stephens, adapted by Kevin Lane Dearinger, and produced for radio by Samuel Lockridge.


The play features Mark Mozingo as Algernon, Paul Thomas as Lane and Merriman, Samuel Lockridge as Jack, Janet Scott as Lady Bracknell, Raylee Magill as Gwendolen, Amelia Collins as Cecily, Catherine Pleis Gaffney as Miss Prism, and Shayne Brakefield as Canon Chausible.


THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST was originally sponsored by Melissa Lebus Watt and Debra Hensley - State Farm Insurance Agent, and Community Trust Bank, with additional support from LexArts and NAI Isaac.

title: CivicLex Digital Town Hall: LGBTQ Resources
brief_description: Join us as we talk with Carmen Wampler-Collins, of Pride Community Services Organization, and Jon Parker, of AVOL, about how Lexington can ensure that the LGBTQ+ community is able to access and receive affirmative care and support during the COVID-19 crisis.
description:
COVID-19 poses compounding threats to the LGBTQ+ community. Higher rates of pre-existing health concerns, lower incomes, and discrimination in the health care system mean that many who may need care won't be able to access it, or fear that they will face judgement, even hostility, if they do. Many may have lost access to affirming social relationships due to distancing measures, as well.

Join us as we talk with Carmen Wampler-Collins, of Pride Community Services Organization, and Jon Parker, of AVOL, about how Lexington can ensure that the LGBTQ+ community is able to access and receive affirmative care and support during the COVID-19 crisis.


Join by computer or phone!

Meeting ID

https://meet.google.com/yik-qjdj-rbq

Phone Numbers

(‪US‬) ‪1-385-404-0975

PIN# 667 575 532


This part of a series of Digital Town Halls that CivicLex has developed in partnership with the Lexington Herald-Leader to keep people informed, engaged, and connected during a time of social distancing. All Town Halls are open to the public and are facilitated by CivicLex Staff. During the forum, participants will have opportunities to talk with each other about the topic at hand. Our Digital Town Halls have a maximum participation of 250.

title: A Vigil for the Victims
brief_description: Please come in Peace and solidarity for the human beings who have been lost, in not only the most recent  and disheartening string of police brutality and RACISM we have ever seen in America present day, but also the many before them.
description:
9:00 am EST. This Sunday 6/7/2020


Please come in Peace and solidarity for the human beings who have been lost, in not only the most recent and disheartening string of police brutality and RACISM we have ever seen in America present day, but also the many before them.


I hope that every Kentuckian regardless of ethnicity, age, gender and class can come as one and hold a peaceful vigil at the Fayette county courthouse steps as a way to honor and remember the black lives lost. Breonna Taylor, George Floyd and Ahmaud Arbery.


We will all Pray TOGETHER, we will say their names TOGETHER, and we will hold a vigil TOGETHER.




🙏🏻🙏🏻Jesus tells us in His prayer:


“…that they all may be one, as You, Father, are in Me, and I in You; that they also may be one in Us, that the world may believe that You sent Me.” ~ John 17:20-21

title: Advocacy From Home
brief_description: For those of us who haven't made it to a protest and can't donate hundreds of dollars but still know we need to take action to fight systems of white supremacy, making calls is something we all can do.
description:
This Thursday starting at 2pm EST, I'll be posting scripts & contact information for government leaders while making calls to express my opinion as a constituent. I plan to contact police departments, the governor, congressional leaders, and the president's office.


I'll share contact info for all these leaders as well as scripts for speaking to them on the phone or dropping them an e-mail. I would love for you to make calls and send e-mails right along with me! I will also offer a video conference for anyone that wants to discuss this process as it goes along.


For those of us who haven't made it to a protest and can't donate hundreds of dollars but still know we need to take action to fight systems of white supremacy, making calls is something we all can do.


To join the video conference:

https://meet.jit.si/MakingCallsforJustice

title: WRITING IN SERIES
brief_description: Harnessing the creative power of our obsessions
description:
WRITING IN SERIES


Sometimes the topics we tackle in our poetry are bigger than the individual poems. Sometimes we write dozens of poems that seem to be related to one another and are part of a larger story. We want to look at a person or an event from different angles, at different stages, talk about it with different voices, etc. IMHO the three important components of writing are instinct, technique and obsession. In this session we will discuss harnessing the creative power of our obsessions to write books. How to make it work? Signs that it's working, signs we need to take a break or move on. Besides the author of award-winning poetry books, Katerina Stoykova is the senior editor of Accents publishing, where she has selected, edited, and published over 80 poetry books. 


Free, with $5 suggested donation 


There will be three identical 60 minute ONLINE sessions

+ 6/27 at 2pm EST

+ 6/29 at 6pm EST

+ 6/30 at 10am EST


To sign up, send an email to accents.publishing@gmail.com

title: Lyric & Life: Black Art in Times of Struggle
brief_description: This intimate talk and poetry reading with Kentucky’s first African American poet laureate
description:
An ONLINE VIRTUAL fundraiser event supporting The Lyric Theatre and Cultural Arts Center's mission!!!

This intimate talk and reading with Kentucky’s first African American poet laureate will consider the role of the artist in bearing witness to the fullness of Black life in and beyond the hardship that overwhelmingly defines our experiences. Engaging the aesthetics of Black art, which have consistently articulated communal struggle and the imaginative practices that move us towards freedom, this conversation will also explore love’s place in liberation and the possibilities of a revolutionary transformation of Black life in this moment of pandemic and protest.

title: Appalshop Special Project: Creating in Place
brief_description: Creating in Place is a collection of original stories, photographs, audio, visual art, and writing both expressing and documenting how individuals in our communities have experienced 2020.
description:
Creating in Place is a collection of original stories, photographs, audio, visual art, and writing both expressing and documenting how individuals in our communities have experienced 2020.

This has been a wild year: the U.S. continues to respond to a pandemic in ways never seen in our lifetime, marches for racial justice are taking place in eastern KY and around the nation, and even the weather has been unpredictable, with late frosts, early heat, and historic storms knocking out many peoples’ power in the spring. We are adjusting in almost every area of our lives, jobs, families, means of being together, and how we take care of ourselves and each other.

Creating in Place brings together original, creative works from the people living these realities. If you’re a community member scrolling through the collection, you might see photographs from a family down the road, read stories from the neighbors you haven’t gotten to see during the pandemic, hear original audio documentaries created by young people, and also contribute your own original artwork to inspire others and build fellowship. If you’re from outside the region and viewing this collection, you will encounter first voice reflections of the region’s complexity, resilience, sorrows, humor, and hope during 2020. Here’s how you can join us, right now:

  • Submit your own photograph! Every week Appalshop will post a new photography prompt under #CreatinginPlaceKY.
  • Contact the director of the project, Becca Finney (becca@appalshop.org) if you have ideas for how you or your community could contribute to the collection. We welcome stories, visual art, writing, photographs, audio, music, you name it.
  • Stay tuned to the collection website and Appalshop social media, because opportunities to get involved will expand in the coming weeks.

title: Lunch with the Arts (Live AND Remote) - Live Pottery Demonstration
brief_description: Join us for a live pottery demonstration with artist Paul Muth of Sugar Grove Pottery & Eclectica.
description:
Join us for a live pottery demonstration with artist Paul Muth of Sugar Grove Pottery & Eclectica. Paul will talk about his background, artistic influences, and personal style. He will also demonstrate the basic process involved in working with clay and throwing pots. If you've never seen a potter's wheel in action, it's a fascinating artistic process!


Registration fee is $5 per person and pre-registration is encouraged. Register online at www.artcenterky.org/lunch-with-the-arts.


COVID-19 NOTES:


We are cautiously optimistic that this program will meet in-person at the Art Center. We will use the Grand Hall and space chairs six feet apart. Masks are required. Due to the space requirements for social distancing, audience capacity will be limited.


We will also broadcast the presentation via live private video feed. Details on how to access the video feed will be sent following registration.


Photo credit: Bobbie Curd

title: Appalshop Watch Party: Dreadful Memories
brief_description: Sarah Ogan Gunning sings about coal strikes & life in Eastern Kentucky on the next Appalshop Watch Party.
description:
“In a society that can honor Loretta Lynn or Emmylou Harris, but not Sarah Ogan Gunning, clearly something is wrong.”

Gunning sings about coal strikes & life in Eastern Kentucky on the next #AppalshopWatchParty.

Join us at 12:30 PM on Friday July 24th to watch for FREE and chat with your neighbors.

You don't have to be alone. Let's ride this out together.


📸 Appalshop, "Dreadful Memories: The Life of Sarah Ogan Gunning," Mimi Pickering, 1988

title: Colored Pencil Landscape Drawing - Online Class
brief_description: Join Instructor Brandon Long to learn about shading,composition, color layering, blending, creating texture and more in this class focused on exploring landscape through the medium of colored pencils.
description:
Join Instructor Brandon Long to learn about shading,composition, color layering, blending, creating texture and more in this class focused on exploring landscape through the medium of colored pencils.

This is an online class and will be facilitated via Zoom.

This class is designed for students ages 14 and up. Registration fee is $60 per person. Register online at www.artcenterky.org/adult-classes.

Colorless blender pencils.

Strathmore bristol paper.

title: A Mask on the Mountains: Dimensions of COVID-19 in Appalachia
brief_description: The world premiere of "A Mask on the Mountains: Dimensions of COVID-19 in Appalachia" — seven stories by young local producers followed by a live Q&A — on our radio station WMMT FM
description:
This year, we invited seven young people to produce audio pieces through our Summer Documentary Institute on the same subject — COVID-19. Their work will air this Thursday at 6 p.m. on our radio station, WMMT 88.7 FM.

The Community Listening Session will be followed by a conversation with AMI Director Willa Johnson and AMI Guest Educator Benny Becker live on AMI’s Facebook page. We need the voices of our young mediamakers now more than ever: local reporters are stretched thin, and national reporters can’t safely visit our region. 

It’s up to us to document what this pandemic is doing to our communities, and to tell our own stories — just like we’ve been committed to doing since young people started Appalshop way back in 1969.

title: Gallery Talk for Open to Interpretation Exhibit
brief_description: Enhance your understanding and appreciation of the Open to Interpretation Exhibit during an online gallery talk with two of the artists from the show.
description:
Enhance your understanding and appreciation of the Open to Interpretation Exhibit during an online gallery talk with two of the artists from the show.

We are pleased to welcome Billy Hertz (Galerie Hertz Art Gallery) and Kayla Bischoff as our guest presenters for this event. Billy and Kayla are both Louisville residents who exhibit regularly at the Art Center.

Join us for a free, one-hour conversation with the artists as they share their creative process and the inspiration behind their vibrant and compelling pieces. Please contact us to register and we'll send you the Zoom link for this event.

You can also browse an online gallery of the exhibit.

description:

As you "Imagine Your Story" for the library's Summer Reading Program, learn how to take your character ideas from your imagination to paper as we draw inspiration from your favorite characters from fantasy, mythology, or fairy tales. This class is provided for free to the public, intended for teens and adults, ages 13+.


Grab a pencil, some paper, and REGISTER at:

BoylePubLib.org/drawing

Zoom call links will be emailed to participants prior to the start of the class.

title: Maybe Baby, It’s You
admission_fee: $20 / adult, $12 / child; $35 / adult, $19 / child for dinner
brief_description: We're getting ready for YOU join us for MAYBE BABY, IT'S YOU, a zany comedy about finding your soul mate!
description:
A mild-mannered Midwesterner whose blind date turns out to be the Greek Goddess of Vengeance; a gorgeous brain surgeon who’s always “Mr. Wrong” because of his wild-and-crazy dancing style; a film noir guy and gal caught in a loop of razor-sharp movie banter; a pair of elderly ex’s possibly reuniting at their grandson’s soccer game. This modern comedy–full of song and dance, love and laughter–takes a tender, funny look at finding your soul mate. Rated G.

Masks will be required until patrons are in assigned seats.

title: Town Hall: Health Disparities
brief_description: Second in a series of town halls hosted by the Mayor's Commission for Racial Justice & Equality
description:
This town hall will focus on the social, cultural, economic, and environmental obstacles African Americans face regarding health and healthcare in Fayette County. It will seek to explore issues of access, insurance, and other factors which explain the chronic health conditions of this population. It will also provide a venue for discussing how the Fayette community at- large and private organizations might significantly reduce these historic disparities.


To submit questions or comments, please email: TownHall@lexingtonky.gov

For more information and link to the Commission YouTube Channel: lexingtonky.gov/commission-racial-justice-and-equality

title: Town Hall: Housing & Gentrification, Law Enforcement, Justice, & Accountability
brief_description: Third in a series of town halls hosted by the Mayor's Commission for Racial Justice & Equality
description:
This town hall will explore the relationships between the city government, police, judicial system and neighborhoods from the African American perspective. It will examine the challenges and conflicts which have historically created a city that is sharply divided along lines of race and class. Additionally, this meeting will explore opportunities for creating a spirit of trust, understanding, respect, and compromise.


To submit questions or comments, please email: TownHall@lexingtonky.gov

For more information and link to the Commission YouTube Channel: lexingtonky.gov/commission-racial-justice-and-equality

title: Town Hall: Racial Equity, Education and Economics
brief_description: First in a series of town halls hosted by the Mayor's Commission for Racial Justice & Equality
description:
This town hall will focus on the distribution of resources in Fayette County and the systematic means by which they are invested. It will also seek to do the following: examine opportunities to fill historic racial gaps in employment, education and business; explore the creation of partnerships among and between Transylvania University, the University of Kentucky, Chamber of Commerce, Fayette County Public Schools, houses of worship, local government and other institutions and organizations which will eradicate systemic racism. Lastly, this meeting will consider the means for sustained outcomes, thereby allowing African Americans to become significant contributors in creating, owning, planning, and investing in future city-wide initiatives.


To submit questions or comments, please email: TownHall@lexingtonky.gov

For more information and link to the Commission YouTube Channel: lexingtonky.gov/commission-racial-justice-and-equality

title: Georgia O'Keeffe Guided Painting Workshop
brief_description: This class is inspired by one of several O'Keeffe paintings created at Lake George, in New York.
description:
Georgia O'Keeffe is particularly well-known for her bold floral paintings, but her abstract landscapes are equally captivating. This class is inspired by one of several O'Keeffe paintings created at Lake George, in New York. Her Lake George paintings all have a similar look, with mountains stretching across the upper third of the picture, a long band of water at the center, and a stand of trees in the foreground.

Your instructor will guide you from blank canvas to finished masterpiece in this three-hour class. All supplies are included and no previous experience is required.


Register online at www.artcenterky.org/starry-night-studio


In the interest of providing maximum flexibility to our students, you can choose to take this class in-person OR online via simultaneous live Zoom. Please select online or in-person instruction at checkout.

The in-person version of this class will adhere to social distancing requirements. One painter will be seated at each table (unless they are members of the same household). Masks must be worn.

The online class will be broadcast simultaneously via Zoom. You will pick up your supplies the day before class is scheduled. An instructional assistant will be present to monitor the Zoom feed and relay questions to the instructor. A two-camera feed provides both a close-up view of the instructor’s canvas and a wider angle that shows the instructor while working.

title: Lunch with the Arts: Sue Ferguson - Fiber Artist
brief_description: Join us for a exploration of fiber art and quilting with artist Sue Ferguson.
description:
Join us for a exploration of fiber art and quilting with artist Sue Ferguson. Sue describes herself as a lifelong lover of fiber – thread, yarn, fabric and fiber - via knitting, crocheting, sewing, weaving, quilting, and needlepoint. For her presentation, Sue will share some of the ways that passion has manifested over time.

Sue attended the State University College at Buffalo, NY and holds a degree in Art Education. She is also the coordinator of the annual quilt show hosted in conjunction with the Great American Brass Band Festival.

Registration is $5 per person. The program will be facilitated Live via Zoom. Register online at www.artcenterky.org/lunch-with-the-arts.


Big thanks to Stuart Powell Ford Lincoln Mazda for sponsoring this event!

title: Butterfly Mosaic Class
brief_description: Create a beautiful mosaic keepsake in this children's workshop.
description:
Create a beautiful mosaic keepsake in this children's workshop. Using a 7" wooden substrate, we'll paint our butterflies, then decorate with mosaic tiles. The substrate has a base that allows it to stand up on its own. Your registration fee includes all supplies.

This class is available both as an in-person workshop AND as a take-home kit. During registration you will indicate your preference for how you want to participate.

Register online at: www.artcenterky.org/kids-classes

title: Fantastic Fishies Painting Workshop for Kids
brief_description: Join us for a guided painting workshop for children ages 6 and up.
description:
Join us for a guided painting workshop for children ages 6 and up. The vivid colors and simple shapes that form our ocean friends make this a wonderful painting for young artists. Students age 10+ may attend independently. Younger artists should bring a supportive adult. (The adult does not need to register separately.)


Register at: www.artcenterky.org/kids-classes


This class is being offered both online and in-person. During registration, please indicate which mode you will participate in.

Notes: The in-person version of this class will adhere to social distancing requirements. One painter will be seated at each table (unless they are members of the same household). Masks must be worn.

The online class will be broadcast simultaneously via Zoom. You will pick up your supplies the day before class is scheduled. An instructional assistant will be present to monitor the Zoom session and relay questions to the instructor. A two-camera feed provides both a close-up view of the instructor's canvas and a wider angle that shows the instructor while working.

title: Van Gogh's Olive Trees - Painting Workshop
brief_description: For this class, we will create an adaptation of Van Gogh's Olive Trees with Yellow Sky and Sun.
description:
Vincent van Gogh painted at least 15 paintings of olive trees, mostly in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence in 1889. Van Gogh found respite and relief in interaction with nature. When the series of olive tree paintings was made in 1889, he was subject to illness and emotional turmoil, yet the paintings are considered to be among his finest works.

For this class, we will create an adaptation of Van Gogh's Olive Trees with Yellow Sky and Sun. Your instructor will guide you from blank canvas to finished masterpiece in this three-hour class. Your $35 registration fee includes all supplies. No previous experience is required.

Register online at www.artcenterky.org/starry-night-studio. Please select online or in-person instruction at checkout.


The in-person version of this class will adhere to social distancing requirements. One painter will be seated at each table (unless they are members of the same household). Masks must be worn.

The online class will be broadcast simultaneously via Zoom. You will pick up your supplies the day before class is scheduled. An instructional assistant will be present to monitor the Zoom feed and relay questions to the instructor. A two-camera feed provides both a close-up view of the instructor's canvas and a wider angle that shows the instructor while working.

title: Constitution 5K / Run for the Arts - COVID Edition
brief_description: The Constitution 5K/Run for the Arts is one of the region's longest-standing and more-beloved races. We weren't about to let COVID-19 force us to break the 42-year tradition.
description:
The Constitution 5K/Run for the Arts is one of the region's longest-standing and more-beloved races. We weren't about to let COVID-19 force us to break the 42-year tradition. The race must go on!!

However...the race committee has made the decision to organize a virtual run this year, as an in-person race cannot realistically conform to the public health requirements currently in place. 300 people panting at the finish line together just isn't wise.

We will still mark out the traditional racecourse through downtown Danville and we encourage participants to run the race on their own schedule during a one-week window starting Sunday, September 20th.


Register online at www.artcenterky.org/run


We have a brand-new special edition t-shirt - inspired by Edvard Munch's classic painting "The Scream" - and you definitely won't want to miss out on your chance to own a piece of history. The COVID-19 race shirt sure to become a collector's item in years to come. This year's shirt is a soft, ring-spun cotton and so comfy you'll want to wear it all the time. Shirts will be available for pickup approximately 2 weeks after race. In the name of frugality in the time of COVID, we are only ordering as many as we need, based on actual registrations.

title: Lexington Chamber Orchestra Rebroadcast: European Postcards
brief_description: Featuring works by Haydn, Vanhal, Mendelssohn with guest artist David Murray, bass
description:
Featuring works by Haydn, Vanhal, Mendelssohn with guest artist David Murray, bass

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the orchestra is unable to offer any live performances for audiences in Central Kentucky for the time being. However, WUKY will re-broadcast several fan-favorite performances to bring concerts right into listeners’ homes — complete with musical commentary from the Maestro.

The performances will air on WUKY’s HD-2 channel, Essential Classics. Listeners who do not have an HD radio or who live outside Central Kentucky can listen online via WUKY.org, with their smart speaker (say “Play WUKY HD Two”) or with the WUKY phone app available from the Google Play Store or Apple App Store.


Since we can’t see you at the concert hall, please consider an online contribution to us!

title: Living With Complexity: A RUX Happy Hour & Case Study Launch
brief_description: Celebrate alongside members of the Kentucky Rural-Urban Exchange family for our launch of "Living with Complexity: 5 Years of the Kentucky-Rural Urban Exchange"
description:
Celebrate alongside members of the Kentucky Rural-Urban Exchange family for our launch of "Living with Complexity: 5 Years of the Kentucky-Rural Urban Exchange", a set of Case Studies examining how RUX works and what the experience has been for many. We'll be celebrating as a Happy Hour, so feel free to bring your favorite snack or drink.


"Living with Complexity" co-authors Ivy Brashear and Richard Young will be joined by featured RUX alumni Ashley Smith, Jim Guthrie, Stacie Sexton, Travis Fugate, Jenny Williams, & Michael George.
